145303326.review:
A friend of mine recommended this game to me ten years ago. At the time, I thought it looked reminiscent in some ways of older indie titles like Braid and LIMBO; a sidescrolling puzzle game with a mysterious storyline. Having finally finished the title, I can certainly say that The Swapper didn't inspire or captivate me in the same way that either of those titles did. What it does have, though, is an extremely solid set of puzzles based around the game's unique mechanics. Just on the gameplay alone, The Swapper justifies itself as a fun and engaging puzzle game with a really impressive difficulty curve that always felt on-point through my entire experience, with every set of puzzles gradually growing more complex while teaching you how to better use the tools you always had available to solve new problems.

The story is another matter, though. I don't hate it. It was interesting enough to keep me engaged through the entire game, but after finishing I can only say that it feels like a mess. Some of the ideas expressed are interesting, but the actual text and story beats never commit to saying anything definite or philosophically meaningful, and the open ends feel less like an invitation to explore the ideas yourself as a player and more like an incomplete narrative that the writer hoped they could pass off as deeper than it actually is by just not finishing it. It isn't actually awful; it just feels incomplete and I would have preferred if it had more meat on the bone. If the puzzles weren't great, I would definitely give it a thumbs down just on the story, but as it happens, the puzzles are great -- play the game for the puzzles and the atmosphere, not the story and the mystery.

10 años después de su salida, The Swapper sigue siendo un juego de puzles apabullante y ferozmente evocador. Esta década entre la primera vez que lo jugué —y que escribí sobre él— y la segunda, si acaso, me ha hecho apreciarlo aún más, y me ha permitido percibir ciertos matices que en su día se me escaparon. Uno de los más evidentes es que, a nivel conceptual, las entidades con las que interaccionas durante todo el juego tienen bastante más que ver con los "elder things" de Lovecraft que con las estelas de Kubrick. Lo cual tiene sentido, si tenemos en cuenta el bagaje de Tom Jubert, su guionista, que empezó en esto de escribir con la saga Penumbra. 

Lo brillante de The Swapper, en cualquier caso, es que puedes hacer caso omiso a la historia, a los diálogos, a los personajes y a la ambientación, y aun así podrías quedarte con un juego de puzles sobresaliente e imperecedero.

It's a nice puzzle game! While the cloning mechanic isn't unique in puzzle world, the specific cloning + swapping puzzle solving is interesting as a mechanic to fill a 4 hour game with satisfying puzzles.

The game map is loosely divided into several sections that each have their own 'theme mechanic', each starting with some simpler puzzles introducing a theme and then upping the complexity from there. There were quite a few puzzles that at first glance seemed absolutely to solve, but with a bit of persevering and reasoning backwards from the target goal of the level, all of them are solvable without a walkthrough!

A layer of philosophical musings about what constitutes the soul, identity and the mind is sprinkled all over the game. While the subject isn't uninteresting per se, the game delivers this content in a way that is a bit self-serious and 'this is so deep' that didn't quite do it for me. Almost all of this content is optional though, so it's easy enough to just let that slide and focus on the puzzles!

136236697.review:
This game took me by complete surprise. I think it's one of dozens of games that I've inadvertently collected over the years through Humble Bundles, and when I was browsing my backlog trying to find something to play, The Swapper did not stand out to me at all. I'm SO glad I gave it a chance.

From the promotional screenshots the visuals were a bit of a turn off, but the game is so different when in motion with the ambiance and musical score playing in the background. It's got a dark, unsettling, and strangely relaxing--or maybe pensive--vibe to it. It's actually very beautiful, which is not what I was expecting at all. The ending can get quite dark, so be warned if you're sensitive to topics of suicide.

The puzzles are wonderful as well. The base concept (creating clones that mirror your movement and swapping places with them) is simple enough to wrap your head around, but the game progresses in difficulty in a very natural way that never feels exasperating. I bounce off puzzle games if I get too frustrated or feel too stupid to figure things out, but this game was very "gentle" in that regard. I'm also very thankful for how forgiving failure is. There's no big deal made, no loading screens, just: you died? Press A to immediately try again.

If I have any complaints it's that there seem to be some UX bugs such as the cursor not working (which can be fixed by going to the Beta branches and selecting "compatibility") and gamepad detection being hit-or-miss.

Other than those things, I loved The Swapper, would recommend it to anyone who's a fan of puzzlers or psychological sci-fi.

[h1]My Rating: 4/5[/h1]

Genuinely gripping existentialist-horror-puzzle game that not only manages to actually tell a compelling story but interweaves it completely with the core mechanics of the game. The clay-molded models and stilted animation and very... contemporary?... lighting set a distinctly uncanny, jarring mood. The inability to tell what the actual material of anything is can be strangely unsettling.

Anyway, shockingly good game, to the point where I feel silly for sitting on it for a decade. Many indie puzzlers from this time period are either dead simple or fail to fulfill simple promises, but The Swapper earns its reputation.

130730520.review:
As a puzzle and exploration fan, I loved this. You're flying around a map and unlocking rooms with puzzles. The initial concept of creating a clone and then transferring your control into that clone gets explored gradually but steadily, and if you ever get stumped there's always at least one other room to solve or path to explore. I would often solve a room, then get stumped on the next, sleep on it, then the next day, I'd beat it and get stumped on the next. It's incredibly fun, and incredibly well-paced and well-made. 

All of these puzzles are incredibly satisfying, and complicated at times - many require good timing and good platforming - but they're never impossible. The controls are very tight and the world has a great sense of weight. 

The story didn't quite land for me, but it's honestly still more interesting than most video game stories. But I do really love the existentialist atmosphere that hangs over everything, just by virtue of the core mechanic, plus there's this sweet, haunting space horror vibe. Perfect for late night puzzling.

129948044.review:
[i]Originally posted on [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/quick-reviews-5/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

A psychosurrealist puzzle game where you interact with the world through a gun that can both create clones of yourself and swap your consciousness between them. The game’s story explores the existential implications of this in excruciating detail. I found both parts quite engaging. The puzzles are appropriately mind-bending in how they require you to be flexible about what you see as “you” and how to organize all your clones, and many of the later puzzles were quite difficult.

My only major criticisms of the story are that a) the ending is very contrived and b) I think it gets too caught up in exploring the implications of its fantasy technology over anything that’s applicable to real life. Like, yes, [i]if[/i] such things as the Watchers and the swapper gun really existed that would have profound implications for existential philosophy, but they don’t, so it’s hard to take anything truly profound from the narrative. But if you enjoy going on a bit of a dive, it doesn’t disappoint.

124233659.review: Beautiful visuals and soundscape, filled with unique artistic design elements throughout the game. Game play core mechanic and story revolves around "swapping" your soul to and/or from a clone. The game utilizes this unique mechanic to create numerous mind boggling puzzles that are extremely satisfying to solve. Voice acting are superb with beautiful writing, albeit the narrative is somewhat cryptic and difficult to understand at times for me. Puzzles have a large range of difficulty, some are solved within minutes, and two of which I was stuck on for more than half an hour. But, that was because I wasn't thinking with portals, I mean... with clones and swaps. Are you the clone? Does the mind exist?

123745612.review:
What if someone knew your mind better than you did?


That is the tagline, and man, this game blew my mind in more ways than one, keep in mind that I will be keeping this as spoiler free as possible.
The swapper is a mind bending puzzle platformer, where your character creates clones to overcome the puzzles presented in the game, and while playing it, you wont be wrong by recalling THAT transporter theory from star trek. I cant go into detail, but if you know, you know. 

The music, sound design, environmental art and even the puzzles amalgamates into transporting the player into another world. No, I did not forget the storytelling aspect of this game, throughout the entire playthrough, the player is given subtle hints as to what the end of the game could possibly be. Yes, possibly be, no matter what you figure out before the end, the possibility still exists that your interpretation could be wrong. The puzzles are also mind bending in the way that whatever direction you walk, or actions you do, your clones will copy you. Here’s the kicker, your clones die and this ties into the story too.

This was the first game I bought and finished while I was in South Korea, so it holds a special place in my heart. It is a very short experience, but for 15 dollars or your regional equivalent, it is well worth the money spent, if you figure out the puzzles first time around, you could be looking at about 4 to 5 hours worth of gameplay, but if you are like me, then, you are more likely looking at about 6 to 8 hours of gameplay. 

This is one of those games that should be streamed without a camera, and minimal interaction with the chat, this game is an experience and if you dont want to experience it for yourself, then hope for a streamer, streaming this game.

This game, was my first indie title as stated before, but it was also the shortest game i have played, that has left me with more questions than answers, it left me with a few days, where i did not want to play any games. That little death that you feel after finishing a great game? I call it gaming's la petite mort.

Play this game, and if you dont want to play a platformer puzzler, or struggle with the puzzles, I will be posting a puzzle solving guide, with no spoilers. This game needs more love. It is such a great game in my opinion, that I would most definitely recommend a purchase.

Recommended if you like mirror image/clone/multi-space-time-dimension type of puzzle game. But the difficulty isn't as hard as others out there imo... So don't expect too much from it.

117283331.review:
The Swapper is a well made and atmospheric puzzle game.

The core mechanic of the Swapper is quite simple: you can create clones of yourself at set locations, move all your clones simultaneously and even swap control into a clone. This deceptively simple idea leads to a variety of interesting puzzles to solve.

The artistic qualities of this game are wonderful. The look of the game is pleasing to the eyes. The use of ambient background sound etc really helps set a particular mood.

There is a mystery to solve and piece by piece small segments of the mystery is revealed.

Overall I'd reccomend this in some kind of bundle.

116972591.review:
Cool premise, but I didn't really like it. The puzzles either felt incredibly easy or frustratingly hard. Multiple speakers all with the same voice and accent made it hard to understand what was happening. The story really had no climax, nor a concrete ending. The map is poorly utilized and hard to navigate (why can't I zoom out and see the whole map???) and the zero-gravity sections made me sick and disoriented.

I judge a Metroidvania by how motivated I am to go back to the unexplored areas... I had no such inspiration in this game. And to top it all off, the achievements are so well hidden that you can't find them without a guide, and if you finish the game you can't go back and get them without starting entirely over again.

Cool Bladerunner music, though.

116938425.review:
A thought-provoking platformer with well-made puzzles and some deep philosophical questions. Does just having thoughts indicate sentience? What is the nature of a soul? Would you still be yourself if your soul left your body and inhabited another? What are you willing to do to survive; moreover, what SHOULD you do to survive? Is survival worth the cost? Are you still human?

If you want a relaxing, linear experience solving puzzles and contemplating fundamental questions of our existence, this game is for you. This game is perfect for people who like putting together pieces of information to discover lore, because the story is notably  and purposefully twisty and ambiguous. I'd recommend playing through it twice; the first to just experience the story, and then a second time to appreciate and realize more about the story. Don't worry; the game is short. Altogether, I spent about 6 hours for two playthroughs. 

Yes, the game is a touch stereotypical, but considering that it was originally released in 2013, it has held up extraordinarily well against the last decade's rapidly growing inclination towards deep philosophical questions. 

Even if you're not great at puzzles, you'll enjoy this game; it isn't too challenging. I myself am not great at puzzles that require this kind of thinking, but I got through about 60% of the game without having to look up a walkthrough, and then on the second playthrough, I was able to do all but three of the puzzles without a guide. 

If any of this appeals to you at all, I'd urge you to give the game a try.

From the great/unique hand made "graphics" to the mind exercising puzzles and great philosophical story, this game won me over from the start and is one that I thoroughly enjoyed.

A metroidvania puzzle game, this game was on my wishlist for years and through  countless steam sales before I finally pulled the trigger.  If that sounds like you, do yourself a favor and buy this game!

I just recently replayed it on my steam deck and the game is still wonderful in 2022!  Puzzles get progressively harder and there are some real head scratchers that are so so satisfying when you finally figure them out.

Weaving in the main mechanic of making and swapping clones into the storyline was a philosophical thought experiment brought to life in a video game.... Absolutely loved it!!!

Takes 5-6 hours to beat. I highly recommend it!!

Easily a top 20 puzzle game for me of all time.  Why you ask?  The game is just so vastly different than any other puzzle game I have played before.  Basically you have to manage switches by creating clones that stand upon them.  Certain spot lights on the puzzle level will block you from either making clones  or teleporting to clones past said light cones.

The graphics and sound are top notch!  The so called models in the game are actually derived from hand molded / manipulated clay.  It truly gives the graphics a sense of organic design that I have never felt in any other game.

113555309.review:
Best to go in blind and just enjoy the perfectly paced experience this dev team has laid out for players.

The atmosphere is beautiful, the assets are actually modeled in real life before being photographed and inserted into the game to give it a unique feel, the music is absolutely astounding, I could go on and on about it's presentation.

Thankfully, from a gameplay perspective - The Swapper is mechanically genius and doesn't throw in an overabundance of new tech/tools/whatever to break your brain. You are given a device that can make copies of yourself and rail-gun your consciousness into said new copy. This is used to solve various puzzles and open up further areas of the ship you make your way through towards completion. 

No words from me on the plot of this game, as I said - best to go in blind - but I do believe the story itself is actually quite engaging and delivered with some great voice acting. 

The less you know about this game, the more it will captivate you. It's length is perfect, never overstaying it's welcome, and the difficulty is tough but rewarding. 

Recommended always.

[h1]Fix the mouse issue please![/h1]

On Windows 10 your cursor will get stuck on the screen where you have to enter your name, making the game unplayable. From what I found on the forums, this issue is quite common and has been occurring since 2017. The game offers a compatibility beta which fixed the issue for me, but a bug like this should have been fixed in the regular version a long time ago.

If your mouse does get stuck:
[list]
    [*]Go to your Steam library
    [*]right-click 'The Swapper'
    [*]click 'Properties...'
    [*]go to Betas
    [*]choose 'compatibility - compatibility'
    [*]close the window
    [*]let Steam download the update
[/list]

For the most part, a solid puzzle game. The core mechanic is interesting, the controls are simple enough to pick up quickly, but allow for some cool exploration, and for the most part, the puzzles provide a good challenge. The mechanic does get a little redundant toward the end, and I would have loved to see an upgrade or something that modified the mechanic a bit to keep the gameplay fresh throughout. That said, the story was very interesting, and the ethical questions posed, as well as the backdrop they're posed against, are a great take on a classic thought experiment. 105433058.review:
The Swapper is a great puzzle-platformer with an amazing atmosphere - and a slight identity crisis. 

The puzzles - which are at the core of the gameplay - are fun and well designed. They all rely on the "Swapper", a device which allows you to create clones of yourself and switch identity with them. None of the puzzles were unfair or tedious, which is a rare thing in this genre. They are designed around tight spaces and elegant solutions and gave me plenty of those "Ah! This way!" moments. They are held together by an incredible dense atmosphere, with brooding or melancholic ambient music, fuzzy lights and empty corridors, nailing this lost-in-space feeling on the head. 

Sadly, the game suffers from the desire to be too much at once, since it also tries to put a huge emphasis on exploration and story, managing neither in the end. 

The overall level design is clearly inspired by Metroidvania-games, with plenty of corridors, a rather free choice where to go next, and a whopping 6 different ways of transport (on foot, through swapping, elevators, big teleports, small teleports, and transportation pipes). However, unlike Metroidvania-games there is not much to explore - no secrets, no extras, only some additional lore here and there. This makes exploration rather dull, and I could not escape the feeling that some of the later game segments did only exist to stretch playtime. 

The story on the other hand is way too deep for the game's limits. The "Swapper" poses questions about the nature of the soul, and at the same time you'll engage cosmic rocks which engage in philosophy via telepathy. Games like Talos Principle were able to show that you can tackle such things if you give them enough room to breathe and to think about. The Swapper, on the other hand, just throws catchphrases like "What is a soul?" at you, which comes out more shallow and uninspired in the end than it probably was intended. There is also another story branch going on, but it is kept equally misterious and only starts making sense within the last 5 minutes or so.

Overall I would have enjoyed the game much more with less emphasis on story and exploration and a bigger emphasis on the puzzles. Because in the end I did not have the feeling that I did everything you could do with such a simple and clever puzzle mechanic - I'm sure that bigger, more daring and multi facetted puzzles would have been possible easily this way.

This sadly also applies to the replay factor: I would love to see the puzzles again one day, but I don't know if I will have the strenght to slog away at the story and running around again. 

Tl;Dr: If you love puzzle games, and if you are a connoisseur of isolationist deep space atmospheres this is a no brainer. If you find space boring, or worse, if you just want to simply puzzle for an evening, you might want to look somewhere else.

102235260.review:
The Game In Short

It's a 2D puzzle platformer, but the focus of the game is almost entirely the puzzles.  The storyline is mixed in with each puzzle which was dark and intriguing.  Unlike most platformers though, there's no enemies to fight or bosses to defeat.  I played through the game once, I don't think I feel a strong urge to play through it again.  I finished it in about 8 hours total which I felt was about right to fit in all major ideas for the puzzles without overkilling it.  I ended up completing it without getting any Steam achievements.  Apparently the achievements are all hidden puzzles scattered about.  Overall its a good game for the price(it's at $15 currently).  I would even go as far as to say it's a "must have" for anyone big into puzzle games.

The Puzzles

Since this game is almost entirely built around solving the puzzles I'm going to focus much of this review on the puzzles themselves(without revealing any spoilers).  The puzzles have a unique mechanic to it, the creating of clones which mimic your movement and the swapping your consciousness between them.  Those that are really into puzzle games will enjoy the different types of thinking this game requires.  Some of the puzzles I figured out almost instantaneously, but most of them I had to put some thought and trial and error into.  They were just difficult enough to provide a feeling of satisfaction and accomplishment for solving each one, without stressing me out in the process. Three or four of them I had to quit and come back on another day with fresh thoughts to solve.  Two of the puzzles I could not solve on my own after putting in a few sessions over a few days(one on Mining Excavation Site 7 and the top puzzle in Metaphysics).  I ended up relenting and checking a YouTube video.  I probably could have eventually got the Metaphysics puzzle on my own but no way could I have gotten MES 7 on my own.  That one was way too convoluted for me.  Very well thought out puzzles overall.

Soundtrack

The soundtrack is mainly ambient sounds and atmosphere, but also has a few minimalist songs here and there.  The soundtrack is worth pointing out because I thought it was very well done and set a correct mood for the game.  I liked a few of the songs so much that I ended up adding them to my YouTube playlist to listen to separately.  In particular liked the Metaphysics puzzle music.

101993615.review:
[b]TLDR[/b] Interesting puzzle platformer with rather simple mechanics, The Swapper stands out due to the tense atmosphere. [18/20⭐, 12h🏅, 3/5💡]

[b]Context[/b] The Swapper is a puzzle platformer where the player is able to create, and simultaneously control, copies of the player character. 

[b]Writing[/b] The player controls an astronaut scavenging an apparently abandoned spaceship. There she finds a device that allows the swapping of minds between bodies, a concept that is central throughout The Swapper’s story.

[b]Aesthetics[/b] What really makes the game stand out is the tense sci-fi atmosphere, from the mysterious plot line to the visuals and minimalistic soundtrack. Films like Alien or Solaris come to mind. Some of the most memorable moments [spoiler]like those floating outside the ship[/spoiler] don’t even involve any puzzle solving. Although I did feel that it lost a bit of the mystique later in the game due to rather crude and expository dialogs.

[b]Gameplay[/b] The gameplay is pretty smooth, even if these are not the most original mechanics (some elements of [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/26800/]Braid[/url] come to mind, for instance). I’d say the puzzle difficulty is medium (I never had to quit in frustration to clear my mind). You can die, but you just respawn at a checkpoint without resetting the level and without penalty, so no gameovers. You can also reset to the latest checkpoint. The game auto-saves but mid-level progress is not saved.

[b]Value[/b] Perhaps The Swapper is a bit short for its (full) price (I completed it in 12h), although I guess to avoid being repetitive the developers would probably have to introduce new abilities or mechanics. You can revisit levels by backtracking and teleporting. There are multiple progress slots. Achievements only relate to finding consoles in hidden rooms, extending gameplay and providing additional context. They do not need an additional playthrough since you can revisit previous levels. There are multiple endings, but determined only by a last-minute decision. Either way, The Swapper is replayable just for the experience (and revisiting the puzzles).

[quote][i]For more puzzle-game reviews and curated lists check out the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43326007-The-Clueless-Adventurer-Puzzle-Trove/]Puzzle Trove[/url].[/i][/quote]

100528360.review: A clever concept done well, The Swapper is a puzzle game with light platforming elements that had me thinking 10 moves ahead with each step. Awakened alone in a spooky space-station setting, you find yourself with the ability to make a limited number of "clones" of yourself which all move simultaneously (to activate switches), but only the one clone that you "swap" into has the ability to collect objects, and create others. Slowly, as you traverse the mysterious relic, a story emerges that questions the nature of consciousness, and identity. The visuals are peculiarly uncanny, as if photographed in miniature, and an ethereal soundtrack completes the effect. A "slow-motion" mode that activates automatically while aiming the cloning ray allows for some death-defying split-second maneuvering, but this game is more about thinking carefully than about twitch action.

- *Replayability value (might not suit everyone, see bad points below)

Bad points:

- Not many, just that the story became so compelling that the last four puzzles (that had ramped up in difficulty) were in the way of the conclusion, so I admit I had to look up a guide for those last few puzzles to find out what happened to our character
- If you are acheivement hunting it is hard to 100% this game without a guide
- *Needs two playthroughs to get both endings (not a con for me per se, but others might be put off by multiple playthroughs)

I really enjoyed playing this game. It made me feel smart every time I solved a puzzle, and as I am new to acheivement hunting it warranted more than one playthrough to be able to see everything. I absolutely adore stop motion claymation projects, so when I watched the into sequence I knew I was in for a great time aesthetically. It worked well with my steam controller (I used mouse like joystick on the right trackpad which felt right to me) and I would recommend this game to anyone in a heartbeat. I loved the philosophical nature of the dialogue between the main scientists, and the messages from the watchers.

Bought this on sale, but would probably recommend at full price with how much I enjoyed it.

92231346.review:
Recommending the Swapper is like recommending the Godfather. Those who have wanted to see it have already seen it and enjoyed it, and those who have heard about it but have not checked it out probably won't get anything out of it, but for the handful of people who haven't even heard of the Swapper...

It's a uniquely bleak sci-fi puzzle game that wears the coat of doomer sci-fi of the 60's and 70's, such as 2001 or Solaris. The game appears to be a simple 'multiple clone of you' solving puzzles, but stretches it into what can only be called Braid level challenges; complex puzzles solved easily with a solution that is right in front of your face. Throw in some truly breathtaking graphics (compliments the vibrant celloid epics mentioned above, as well as a nostalgic sense of PC gaming) with a moody and wonderfully bittersweet soundtrack, some juicy thought provoking questions about existence and what it means to be a clone, and you got The Swapper.

Just the right length, looks and sounds amazing, chewy story, and plays great. You will be scratching your head, not banging your head against a wall with the puzzles. Just damn fine!

84447325.review:
[h1]The Swapper - 9/10[/h1]

A friend of mine made a recommendation for a puzzle game, right after we played some Portal 2 - and boy, I wasn't expecting this masterpiece of a game. There is only one drawback in my opinion, but more to that later. 

In the 2D world of The Swapper, we control a female scavenger aboard a seemingly abandoned space station, and we soon discover the title-giving apparatus that will lead us through our whole adventure: a swapping device that lets us create and teleport to max four copies of ourselves. While only one of those copies can be the one that we control (and "live" in) directly, any other copy will perform the same move as we do. We jump right into the well written narrative (I won't spoil you too much here) and discover the different sections of the station in order to solve not only the game puzzles, but also the puzzling story that is well placed in this dark and lonely world, only to be filled by us and our own copies at first.

The puzzles will introduce you to the swapper mechanics, soon introducing a whole lot of environment changes that you will have to adapt to - swap-or teleport-stopping light, moving platforms, gravity (which nearly lets you forget that it's only 2D) and large chasms that let you fall to death if you aren't quick enough to swap and port yourself to your next copy.

Soon, you will get the same thoughts that I had: am I killing myself here, or is the just created copy me and it was just a picture of me that faded away? Kinda spooky...
The background music is rather enjoyable and relaxing,  as is the pace if the game. The way is quite linear, and every real puzzle is set in a closed room that let's you solve it independently. Certain gateways require you to have a number of "orbs" that you get for solving puzzle rooms, sometimes you can chose between which room is next, but eventually you will have to do them all - plus, you WANT to do them all, because the beauty of the game lies in the well-thought puzzles. 

Yes, definitely, it will get harder ans harder. One piece of advice: make a pause,  come back later, try again differently - they are not undoable.

The only negative thing is the "shortness" of the game. While it is surely repeatable (and if you want to experience both endings, you would habe to play it twice as you can't load a savegame, instead you play from the last checkpoint), it is over quite fast - I have about 8 hours on record, some of that time went into try and repeat, some into thinking hard and staring at the beautiful scenery, but also some idling in the background - so I guess you can do it in 4-6 hours with concentration.

Overall, a very very very good game, I am only sorry to not have discovered it before - although it's 7/8 years old, it did not lose any of its magic, gameplaywise, storywise, even graphics - gloomy, dark, entwined background, perfect match for the intense storyline,  if you like dark sci-fi settings. 

Very stringly recommended!
Thank you for reading.

82587684.review:
[i]Standard disclaimer: Play clock inaccurate; offline time not counted[/i]

[i]The Swapper[/i] is a game with an interesting premise that was, sadly, let down by poor design choices. It had a lot of potential, but couldn't deliver on it. While it does have its worthwhile points, it is overall an unfulfilling experience. The fact that I had to opt in to a "compatibility [i]beta[/i]" to play the thing is not a good sign in any light.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
On the face of it, [i]The Swapper[/i] has a relatively pretty game, with detailed environments and a good soundscape working for it. Visually, it's clearly inspired by the likes of [i]Metroid[/i] and a variety of abandonpunk titles, but with enough of a twist that it doesn't feel too derivative. Its appearance is somewhat inconsistent with the stated setting, but that's fine; not everything has to come out of a cookie cutter, so let's be happy that someone decided to innovate. It's also a game to play with headphones, as its soundscape is on the whole immersive and really quite lovely. Well, except for the soundtrack and UI, but more on that later.

The core design concept of being able to clone yourself, either as a "do as I do" automaton or so you can "swap" your consciousness into the clone, really adds dimensions to the game. It opens the door for some extremely creatively designed puzzles and encourages some nonlinear thinking to solve puzzles; you need to think in multiple places at once. Players who like to pick at puzzles, trying multiple paths and approaches and iteratively developing a solution will probably love the design; I know I did!

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
First off, the game has some core engine issues. On start, the game was unplayable, with a jammed mouse cursor. It took a trip to the forums and an opt-in to a compatibility beta to even play it. For a title that's been out this long, a bug that renders the game unplayable is inexcusable.

While the bulk of the game's puzzles are interesting and well designed, but there are several which devolve into needlessly frustrating split-second timing events with no tolerances. That's fine if the puzzle is the right length, but having to redo large sections because you blew one fractional-second timing step is annoying. Players with a low tolerance for frustration may want to give this one a pass.

While the atmospheric sound is a delight, the UI SFX and "soundtrack" (such as it is) are just painful. Since there's no way to turn it off, that's definitely a point against the game.

Finally, while there's an interesting setting just begging for story, the story itself is poorly presented and delivered. It feels thin and uninspired, leaning heavily on philosophical implications that have been reused dozens of times in other works, and forgetting that there needs to be a worthwhile plot to thread it together. Ultimately, the plot is very derivative of many other sci-fi works, with a thin coat of paint slapped on and obfuscated with philosophical fluff.. Since the writing for this title fell out of the head of Tom Jubert, that shouldn't be a surprise; Subnautica and FTL were similarly xeroxed stories, and this follows the tradition of minimal-effort writing. Lots of potential, but almost completely squandered.

[h1]The Bottom Line[/h1]
Ultimately, it's a good puzzle game with a clever design concept, but saddled with weak tea for a plot and some pretty annoying bottlenecks to deal with. If nonlinear puzzles are your thing and you have patience enough to deal with multiple reruns of a puzzle before you hit a solution, then this one might be right for you - but only on sale. The weak writing, questionable audio, and lingering technical issues mean it's in no way worth full price.

78459210.review:
I only shut down this game because i needed to get food. I think if i had snacks nearby, i would've finished it in one go.

This is some amazing gameplay. You are a spaceperson exploring an abandoned space station, which is in orbit around a planet, which is being mined for telepathic rocks. You solve environmental puzzles by creating up to four clones of yourself, which mirror your actions. You can transfer control to any one of the clones. As you explore the station, you uncover more of what happened to the crew, by way of a mysterious woman who communicates with you over intercom, and a series of messages you read on monitors scattered around the place. There's lots of existential commentary in this game, it's nothing groundbreaking, but it's interesting and well implemented, and serves the story well.

The puzzles are ingenious. Many are pretty straightforward as long as your brain's switched on, but some... mate, some of them are proper conundrums. It's a good feeling when you figure those out. The player character is never in any danger, unless you count suicide by falling. There are no bad guys, nobody's shooting at you, no flesh chomping traps, NOTHING. And yet this game still somehow cultivates a gripping sense of urgency which does not let go. 

The visual design is reminiscent of Neverhood, it has a surreal, clay-like aesthetic to it. The character you control feels like a real human. The animations are eerily realistic, and the way s/he ragdolls is quite visceral. The design of the space station itself triumphs in presenting an eerie, desolate, and very lonely atmosphere.

The sound design is similarly awesome. The music is scarce, minimal, and very brooding. The sound effects are well chosen, and serve to punctuate the relentless quiet of the sinister landscape.

Bottom line, play this game, you won't regret it. Unless you hate good things.

75889973.review:
The Swapper is a beautiful game - I felt that when starting it for the first time. What I wasn't expecting was for it to draw me in so completely, after the matter of a few levels. The mechanics are pretty much what is described on the store page, that you can create a certain number of clones, and swap control between them. One thing I really admire about this game. It makes your brain unlock, your imagination of this simple tool unlock, instead of unlocking things for the tool itself.

Legit:
+ Incredible handmade visuals
+ Great soundtrack
+ Extremely good story
+ Optional logs to add depth to storyline
+ Rock Memos
+ New mechanics keep the story fresh

Right out the gate: every item in this game was a physical clay model that has been transposed into the game. Lighting is a core mechanic to puzzles. What results is probably the most beautiful 2D game I've ever seen.
So this was a hell of a find. I'm a big fan of old-fashioned big thinky high philiosophy science fiction novels. I didn't expect to get that itch scratched so well out of my steam library. Especially from a game I ignored for so long.

You play as an astronaut send to rescue and investigate a ship where something went terribly wrong. Upon landing, you discover a device that lets you duplicate yourself and swap your conscious around those bodies. It seems you are alone, but that's only half true. A consciousness exists within the ship, and its origin is as mysterious as the objects it inhabits.

So hows the gameplay? Kinda fun! It's not something I wouldn't bore of eventually, but the game thankfully doesn't overstay the welcome. Moving clones around and bouncing between bodies is a lot of fun, and the puzzles are a perfect balance of approachable and satisfying. It would have been very easy for the developers to make this a "lets laugh at the silly physics" game. But they didn't. the tone of the story demands otherwise, and the physics are very well done. Likely my favorite thing to do is make a clone way above your head, swap to it, and keep doing this indefinitely to skip elevators. You can do this indefinitely, as the old clones will die below you with a disturbing crunch. It's like having a jet-pack made of compound fractures.

How's the story? I expect I already showed my hand. To be frank, you won't find much in the way of character development, but that isn't the point. The ideas the game lobs at you about the nature of consciousness is staggering. The backstory of what's happening on the ship is both eerie, inspiring, and tragic. Every single tone was hit perfectly. This is only amplified by the "FANTASTIC" sound track and sound design. The sounds of swapping, breaking bones, doors, every effect is perfect.

Replayability? If I were to play this again, it would be to re-experience the story and visuals. The puzzles serve their purpose, but any old guide could make this a two hour experience if that's what you want. I highly recommend you solve them legitimately the first go-around though. I did look up the locations of the ten secrets, though. I'm not some kind of mega-brain super rock.

74387493.review:
[i] The Swapper [/i] is everything that I wanted out of a puzzle platformer made by a small studio. 

The attractive visuals are unique, the gameplay is clever, the soundtrack and audio is effective in its minimalism and most importantly, the story is interesting. Unfortunately, just about all of the indie games I've played before have downright dreadful storytelling or the developers just didn't seem to try to inject anything that could hold my attention. An interesting story is important to me. It keeps me going and stops my frequent glances at the clock. 

Unlike many other indie games, [i] The Swapper [/i] didn't wear out its welcome and actually exceeded my expectations. Many will look to the likes of Braid or Limbo as landmark titles, setting the standard which led to the great indie developer explosion. Perhaps they are, but [i] The Swapper [/i] and it's more narrative-driven approach has iterated and refined upon what came before it, leaving me to think that many of the so-called indie greats of the past are not so special after all and are in some cases, pretentious.

I will make sure to keep an eye out for anything else that the writer, Tom Jubert, has contributed to.

This was really a hidden gem. I've had this game in my collection for a long time. Probably bought it in some bundle that was up for sale and then it was left forgotten in the dark depths of my collection.

I decided to try it after reading some good reviews and I was not disappointed.

It is a short game. It took me 5 hours to finish, and I know that this was a very slow run. However, the puzzles are interesting, the atmosphere is well built, controls work perfectly, and the graphics are very much on point.

This is a 2d platformer and puzzle game, and nothing more than that (so stay away if you don't like those). However, it is a very well implemented one, with a very clever mechanic that I haven't seen in other games. The level design was well thought out and it manages to not be repetitive, even if the story develops basically in a single place. Speaking of story, it is interesting; I was pleased that there was one, but it is nothing fantastic. The way it is revealed during gameplay keeps the interest on the rise, so I have to give props to the devs for that.

Anyway, I highly recommend this game if you like puzzles and want to spend a few hours.

71778620.review:
The honest answer from will have to be "pass", but this could be worth your money depending on your preferences. This is a gorgeous, atmospheric puzzle game. In fact the creators did such an amazing job using visuals and sound effects to create such an immersive experience I almost recommended it based on that alone.  Sadly, it is just too short and the gameplay too shallow.  The gameplay is based on you being able to create up to four clones of yourself that, once created move exactly as you do. You also can only control one at a time as the primary agent.  It then adds in environmental modifiers that allow you to change whether or not you are upside down or right side up and also control where you can create clones and when you can swap with them.  From these constraints the puzzles arise.  I did want to go easy on this game because you can tell from the credits that it was created by a very small team. But, even still I thin kthere is too little content. As you can see I have five and half hours on record. That was to beat the game and I was really taking my time. 

Summary:

Graphics: 10/10 - Excellent, artistic utilization from a small team.
Music/SFx - 9/10 - Beautiful, immersive
Story - 7/10 - Well written, but predictable. Standard sci-fi existentialism.
Controls - 7/10 - Fine for what you need them to be. The aim acts like a mouse pointer which feels awkward a lot because the game does not include enough fine tuning for such utilization (speed only, no control of acceleration, option for snapping, etc.)
Gameplay - 2/10 - The puzzles are so easy they are barely there.  I could have beat the game in 4 hours if I had been in a hurry.  It is more like a "experiential" game, and I would have been less offended had it been advertised this way.

If you are into easy, experiential games, this could be worth your time but it is so short still not at it's standard price. Deep sale only or not at all.

The Swapper is a platformer puzzle game using a cloning gun. 

You can create up to four clones of yourself that will copy your exact movement. You can also swap yourself to any of them if you have direct vision. The game time is slowed down when you are holding down the create clone button. The later levels get harder and might take about 30 minutes to figure out when any of their time to execute takes up to 2 minutes each.

The story ties in very well with the game's core mechanic, the cloning and will leave you thinking. It all leads up to the hard decision where you have to choose between the two endings.

While I didn't have mouse problems, many players are complaining about it. The fix is to enable the "compatibility" version from the Betas tab. More information here https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1212814284

69763080.review:
Note: If having difficulty moving the mouse when you first launch the game, close it and try this:
Right click "The Swapper" in your Steam Library > Properties > Betas > Compatability mode (In the dropdown menu)

The Swapper is an atmospheric, indie puzzle game that presents difficult and interesting puzzles, as well as  interesting philosophical questions. It's the sort of game that makes you think during and after your playthrough. The game takes place on a seemingly derelict research base orbiting a remote planet. There are some magical moments!
The game has a convincing atmosphere that drew in, the music suiting the setting but never overbearing. (In some areas it is beautiful!)
Length: approx 6-7h
Difficulty: starts easy, increasing in difficulty as new mechanics and ways of manipulating "the swapper" device are taught to the players. Some very tricky (and satisfying) puzzles at the end. Very forgiving checkpoint/autosave system.
Vibe/Mood experience: Relaxed, no pressure, take at your own pace. Some intense themes towards the end. You can immerse and play for a couple of hours. I wouldn't oplay longer than 2h sessions

WOULD RECOMMEND
It was an especially great change from my more intense FPS games.
I bought this game on sale, add it to your wishlist and do the same.

I'll be adding a couple of reviews as I play through my 50 game backlog. If you enjoyed this, follow and you might see some more reviews from me!

69687302.review:
I received this game though Humble Bundle some years ago. I first played this game for about an hour, mostly for the trading cards and I got stuck on a puzzle at one point, about an hour into the game and gave up at first. 
Eventually, I decided to play again five years later, see what the story was about. It took me about five hours to complete the game. 
The graphics style was a little unusual, considering most of the game takes place on a space station, but it looks like most of it is made of stone rather than metal.
The gameplay mechanic, cloning and swapping, is fairly unique to this game and few other games (including Forget me Not Annie) have a similar mechanic.
While I was able to figure out most of the puzzles in this game, there were at least four that I had to look up on Youtube in order to complete them. You need to complete all the puzzles in order to finish the story.
The achievements are extremely well hidden and cannot be spotted in plain sight. You'd have to walk against the walls or launch yourself against the ceiling, or spam the clone button at both, in every room, in order to find them all without a guide.
The story was pretty good, a bit stoic, but it was a great five hours.
7.1/10

Note: The game may bug out when you first start it up. You mouse cursor may stick to one area of the screen in the main menu, which interferes with the menu. If you have this issue, exit, go to beta options, select compatibility mode and start the game up again, there should be no problems then.

69640295.review:
The core of the game comes down to solving a series of puzzles to collect keys and progress to the next set of puzzles.  All of the puzzles rely on the game's one, not-really-that-unique mechanic of summoning a mimic who you can jump to in certain situations.  The lack of variety in mechanics limits how far the puzzles can go and, combined with the short length of the game, makes for a weird difficulty curve that jumps from pretty basic for most of the game to requiring really specific sequences in the final two or three.  The biggest problem, though, is that the dark aesthetic and imprecise movement don't fit well with gameplay that demands split-second reactions and accurately estimating distances.  The rewarding feeling of figuring out the process behind the occasionally complex puzzle is turned to frustration after half a dozen resets because your placement was a few muddy pixels off.

There's also a story going on in the background about a generic derelict space station that brought something they shouldn't have on board, but it doesn't really do much to explain or resolve anything, it's more about creating a spooky atmosphere than anything.  If anything, it hurts the game due to how badly it meshes with the gameplay.  It's bad enough that the mess of corridors leading to dead-end puzzle rooms is supposed to be a place people lived and worked in or how parts of the story directly contradict how the mechanics work, but needing to travel between each level with the slow, clunky controls so the game can pretend it's more than a series of linearly-progressing levels is just a pain, especially with how many times you have to drop down from ledges just above the fall death height.

Ultimately, it's too simplistic and unpolished to be worth picking up over similar titles and massively overpriced for how little content it contains.

69495405.review: Normally I despise side scrollers. However, The Swapper is very low key and puzzle-centric. The game mechanics are interesting, the puzzles are engaging without being too tricky, the story is intriguing without being demanding, and the scenery is beautiful. No stunts requiring perfect timing, no killing, just puzzles and exploring. A nice, laid back, relaxing diversion.

69493687.review:
The only reason I'm not recommending The Swapper is the price is a little high for what it is. Unfortunately for The Swapper, I played it back-to-back with Limbo and it's hard not to draw comparisons as they're very similar games being both puzzle platformers about three hours in length with minimal story.

The Swapper's puzzle design is a good example of "thinking [i]inside[/i] the box", particularly when compared to Limbo's distinctively "out of box" thinking. The puzzles aren't bad by any means, but The Swapper doesn't try anything new and it's fairly clear that the only thing that separates The Swapper from a simple browser based Flash game is the presence of a game engine giving it a graphical uplift and a world you can navigate around between the puzzle rooms. Take those away and you'd have the traditional screen full of numbered boxes that you choose the next puzzle from each time. What's absurd is that it's blindingly obvious the game's barely more than a browser game and yet you're still being charged £12 for it.

Overall the atmosphere and tone are really good, the world is eerily beautiful, the puzzles are okay and the story is a little superfluous. If this game were half the price then I'd recommend it, but as it is it's just too expensive for what you get. Comparatively, Limbo is a smarter and more engaging work of art for almost half the price.

66888243.review:
A 2D puzzle platformer with a pretty unique mechanic: you have a ray gun that can create clones as well as swap 'souls' with them. The clones copy your movement, but cannot interact with objects or use the ray gun, and you can only have a set number of clones at a time. You use this mechanic to move your 'main body' around to either travel to different destinations or solve the puzzles.
 
The puzzles in the game require you to collect these orbs (only your main body can do so) that are required to power the numerous teleporters you encounter in the game to travel to different locations. There are obstacles that get in your way of collecting the orbs, but I will refrain from mentioning them. The puzzles are all based on how you use the game mechanics and are perfectly logical without having absurd numbers of steps, while still being challenging enough to leave your head-scratching and to give a great sense of achievement once you complete one (there was one puzzle that I couldn’t solve without looking up the solution, and I consider myself good at puzzles, so be prepared to search for solutions online).

The unique mechanic aside, the graphics are beautiful and the atmosphere is immersive in the sense that you really feel like you’re in a deserted space station with the dramatic lighting and chilling sound effects. The story is deep, if a bit cryptic, which is rare for a puzzle game, and it slowly unfolds as the game progresses. There’s also good freedom of exploration as some areas are optional to explore. The map display indicates unexplored areas as well as the location of the orbs so that you can go straight to solving the puzzles if you don’t feel like exploring everything. 

To sum it all up, this is a puzzle game with an innovative game mechanic backed up by beautiful graphics and immersive atmosphere and driven by a good story, while still allowing some freedom of exploration. However, it is still a puzzle game in essence, so if you don’t like the idea of busting your mind to solve puzzles, then you won’t enjoy this game, as can be seen from some negative reviews. The puzzles are the basis of the gameplay, the rest is navigating through the space station while uncovering the story. There are no enemies to fight. 

If you like puzzle games, then this game is gonna be a real treat. As a puzzle lover, it truly was a wonderful experience for me. I dare call it a masterpiece, even. I never thought that a puzzle game could make me feel that way. The only downside is there isn’t much replay value, to me at least, despite there being an alternate ending, which you need to start a new playthrough if you want to see it. While I would like to retry some of the puzzles, the thought of navigating the huge space station once more is daunting, at least for now, though I enjoyed it the first time. It would have been nice if you had the option to select individual puzzles to replay after completing the story once, sort of like level-based puzzle games. On that note, if you just want to rush through the puzzles, then you might find navigating through the space station a bit tedious, but if you like puzzles, then you should already have some degree of patience! XD

64521386.review:
[quote=one hearer]The world is the limit of thought. The limit of thought is the chain of hearers like me. I cannot speak if they cannot listen.[/quote]

The Swapper es un magnífico juego de puzles cuya mecánica principal está basada en la clonación y en el intercambio entre personajes. Tiene un muy buen diseño de niveles, donde la dificultad va subiendo progresivamente, sin llegar a ser frustrante ni injusta (aunque algunos de los últimos puzles tienen su miga).

El apartado artístico está bien, tanto los gráficos como los sonidos crean una buena atmósfera (sin ser tampoco nada del otro mundo). Donde acierta de pleno el juego es en su guión. Por medio de terminales y unos pocos diálogos, se va deslavazando una trama compleja, con toques de terror psicológico, y que ahonda en cuestiones filosóficas como la consciencia del individuo.

En general, este juego me ha parecido una pequeña joya (pequeña porque no dura mucho, en torno a 3-4 horas) por lo completo y bien diseñados que están tanto sus puzles como su historia (por cierto, los texto están íntegramente en inglés, pero no es un inglés especialmente complicado).

Una cosa mala del juego son los logros. Si eres de los que les gusta conseguirlos, debes saber que es prácticamente imposible sin mirar guías, son terminales que están excesivamente escondidos.

En resumidas cuentas, si te gustan los juegos de puzles, éste es una muy buena opción, y si además buscas una buena trama, The Swapper es tu juego.

✪✯✪✯✪✯✪ [h3]7.5 / 10[/h3] ✪✯✪✯✪✯✪

64425222.review: Good puzzles. Nice atmosphere. Pleasant ending.

64266417.review:
This game is so underrated! It has platforming and puzzle elements, and they work very well. Once you figure out what should be done, it almost never feels cheap. You get the satisfying "aha!" moment every puzzle should have.

The real strength of this game is its atmosphere and concept. I know cloning has been done to death, but this just feels so fresh. Each stage has a distinct character and each is gorgeously crafted. It's all incredibly meticulous. There are a few themes, and every part of the game echoes and reworks them: the gameplay, the entities you encounter, the choices you are given, the arcs of the other character(s). That's why I feel that the plot isn't too sparse, because the rest of the game is constantly having a dialogue with you about its core issues, without relying on cutscenes. I was afraid they would get too in your face about it, but it's more of a slow, morbid realisation about what you've been doing this whole time.

overall, amazing! Short game! 10/10! Play it as an afternoon snacc then go reflect about the meaning of consciousness!

63140180.review:
Swapper is a brilliant struggle for survival on a derelict space station that's riddled with moderately-difficult puzzles, stupendous voice acting, and a gripping story that touches on the philosophical without being ham-fisted or over-indulgent.  The simple controls let you focus on the puzzles while still having enough concentration left over to drink in the barren atmosphere of this once-populated orbital research facility.  There are minimal platforming elements, with all puzzles focusing more on the order of operations than on just-frame timing to roflstomp a goomba.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone interested in puzzlers, story-driven games, or sci-fi elements, with it being all but a mandatory download for people who enjoy all three!

62344710.review:
[b] Disclaimer: [/b] As of January 17th, 2020, Mouse controls are still completely broken; a gamepad is required.

"The Swapper" is a puzzle game with a few platforming aspects. Much like "Portal" there is a single key mechanic that is fully explored and utilized throughout the entire game. And just like you had to "start thinking with portals," you now must start thinking with the swapper.

[b] Puzzles 9/10: [/b] Every puzzle requires the player to learn the mechanics of the titular swapper, and then experiment, and apply them in new ways. While only a couple of the puzzles near the end might be considered "hard," frankly they are all incredibly well designed. The difficulty varies with your understanding. My only complaint is that I feel they could have been a bit more complex close to the end.

[b] Story 6/10: [/b] The story is intriguing and does its best to shove science and philosophy together. I enjoyed it, but it's not very special.

[b] Graphics 7/10: [/b] At first the textures look a bit odd, but they quickly grow on you, and suit the game's aesthetic very well. Platforms and effects also have pixel perfect hit-boxes, so a big plus there.

[b] Sound 8/10: [/b] Every little noise and bit of music comes together to form a vaguely creepy, yet beautiful atmosphere. You really FEEL like you're in space. My only small issue is that airlocks sound like you're in water.

[b] Voice Acting 5/10: [/b] It works well.

[b] Good Design: [/b] Camera rotates with you in zero-g. Gravity is not constant through the entire space station. The map rotates as you do.

[b] Design Issues: [/b] There are a few random areas where you cannot use your swapper, with no explanation. It can get rather tedious being slowed whenever you walk past certain objects.

[b] Overall: 8/10 [/b] An extremely well-made puzzle game.
[b] Personal Enjoyment: 9/10 [/b]

Clocking in at between 1 and 8 hours for a first play-through, I'd hesitate to say that this game is worth $15. Personally, as a lover of puzzle games, I think it is. But for casual puzzlers, you should get it on sale.

61053238.review:
[It has been a while since I played this game.]  
I was enjoying this initially.  It was a puzzle game; you have to solve puzzles to literally move forwards.  Suddenly, there was a point at which I could not progress.  There is a place that appears to be the next puzzle, but I could not solve it.  (I think they put it there expressly to annoy people.)  [This is not a spoiler, because there is a gigantic arrow pointing to where you have to go.]  It turns out that you have to stand at a certain spot (not at that putative puzzle), marked with a gigantic arrow pointing upwards... and replicate yourself as high as possible, and then immediately replicate yourself upwards again... such that you end up standing on a ledge.  I felt deeply betrayed.  * Suddenly it is not a puzzle, but instead is about fast and accurate mouse movement -- that is, sheer dumb luck.  * You can not see the ledge you are aiming for, so you can not plan your mouse twitch (not to mention that fact that the whole screenful moves *continually during* [**continually during**] the manoeuvre).  * I imagine that the idea is that the character can see the ledge, but the player can not, so that is just insulting.  * You have to kill yourself repeatedly, trying to be lucky and get the right mouse twitch.  I never had any sense that there was any real skill involved; quite the opposite.  The game premise is that you (i.e. the game protagonist) are exploring, and have the swapper gadget; I can not imaging myself leaping blindly upwards, hypothetically killing myself repeatedly, with no hope of attaining the ledge except eventually absolutely by luck/accident.  There is no sense of achievement for the player in the real world; just the experience of multiple simulated suicides.  Call me strange, but I do not enjoy this.  

I do not think there is any sense in which the thing counts as a puzzle.  (If they deleted the giant arrow, only some sort of obsessed manic would ever find out how to progress.  Indeed, a normal, rational person would put the same effort into solving the decoy non-puzzle.)  If it is the only such instance, then they should never have put it in... but I suspect that the whole game from then on is full of such achievementless non-puzzles.  I shall never know.  

This is not a puzzle game.  I would have asked for my money back, but I believe there is a 2-hour limit on that.  It feels strongly like the whole thing exists just to get you to the three hour mark before you realise that you were tricked out of your money.  It made me hate Steam as well, because of all those suicides.

59859045.review:
It's a good puzzle game. I give it 4/6. It's not amazing, but pretty good. I didn't really understand the narrative of the story, but it seems my brain has a hard time following stories. I tend to focus on the puzzles. You are in space in a spacesuit and equipped with a tool: the swapper. With it you can make copies of your self and move ur 'soul' to one of the copies. You can maximum make 4 extra copies, for a total of 5. So the swapper tool can do these two things: make a new copy and change which copy you control. Additionally time slows down almost to a still when you make a copy, something you often have to make use of. In the puzzles there are lights that prevents the swapper gun from doing certain things. By placing clones of your self or boxes you can disable these lights. All the clones move identically when you move around. You have to strategically place the clones with this in mind.
The game is quite beautiful with it's lighting and I like the music too. I found the quotes that you encounter during gameplay weird and nonsensical, like something a stoner would say trying to be profound. Sort of annoying, but I enjoyed the rest of it.
I was sort of surprised how quickly the game ended and wised there were more challenging puzzles. It takes some time for the brain to adopt the weird thinking that is required to solves the puzzles using the swapper gun.

59594134.review: This is what I look for in a puzzle game. The central mechanic of the game is interesting, and it is actually well-executed. The puzzles themselves are challenging, but the solutions are always logical. The story is nothing special, but I've played enough puzzle games where the story actively harms my enjoyment to appreciate solid but unspectacular. Overall it's a great way to spend several hours.

58998229.review:
Atmospheric puzzler

Ship is busted, you seem to be all alone, and something has contaminated the ship. Better solve some puzzles.

The Swapper's game play allows the player to create duplicates which mimic the players movement. You can also swap "souls" which alters which body the player controls. Puzzles have lights that restrict the ability of the player to make clones or to swap bodies. As one progresses, the puzzles naturally become more challenging though I would say they aren't too difficult.

What really helps the game to stand out is the atmosphere. The developers do an excellent job of conveying a story with minimal interactions. Mostly consoles let the player to learn what happened as well as dabble in philosophy. The visuals are nice as well.

Overall I would say this is a charming game.  Everything works, there is attention to detail, and the game doesn't overstay it's welcome by dragging on. Not the most challenging puzzle game I've played, but definitely work the look if you liked Hitman Go or other casual puzzlers.

Actually a fun, cool looking puzzle game.
At first I was just hooked by the artstyle of the game, because it looked fairly unique. After starting it up the somewhat dark, mysterious and a bit claustrophobic space-atmosphere pulled me in. I really liked it.
Followed by the first pretty easy puzzles I thought, this is gonna be a quick one, but I was wrong. Some of the puzzle really need some good thinking and timing which makes them a bit more demanding than I initially expected. Big up!

The only bad thing that came across my mind are the achievments ( this is pretty specific and it does not really influence my position towards the game itself - but still, I wanted to mention it).

## POTENTIAL SPOILER ##
[spoiler] Personally I think the achievments are UNREACHABLE without looking them up 100%. The hidden rooms are so well hidden that you cannot stumble across them out of luck or by chance. And since the achievments on steam themself do not tell you anything aswell, nobody gets any clue to look out for. [/spoiler]
## END SPOILER ##

And in addition to this, if you finished the game once ( collected all 124 Orbs and activate the last console thingy) - there is a point of no return where you cannot replay any level to hunt the achievment without restarting the whole game (and overwrite your progress)

All in all, as I said, this does not influence my opinion of the game - It's still a beautifull unique styled puzzle game with a good few hours of fun, ponder and  despair :)

[u] Gameplay [/u]
In this science fiction-themed title, the player controls a female scavenger stranded aboard an abandoned research station, and discovers a strange device that allows her to create clones of herself and switch her consciousness between these clones. The player uses this ability to solve various puzzles and learn about the fate of the station's researchers.

[u] Review [/u]
I'm not a favourite when it comes to puzzles but I did quite enjoy this one, despite the few difficult puzzles I came across which I needed help on (Thank you guides!) The story left me a little confused, it didn't help that I got bored reading all the data logs since some of them had a lot of text and i'm more of a player than a reader. I wouldn't have had any problems if there was an audio. Apart from that the story is interesting and actually pretty creepy.

The reason why you should get this on full price is because the game isn't half bad and it looks like this small company put a lot of effort into it which always goes a long way for me, even if it's a pretty short game.

Maybe i'm a watcher?

■■■■■■□□□□ 6 / 10

The concept of duplicating the character(s) and swapping them are cool, but other than that the game contains your typical game mechanics and average puzzle challenges. I am surprised they didn't fix a number of serious issues with the game even after players complaint about them. For examples: 1) The incompatibility issue at the beginning of the game (players should not have to troubleshoot the game) -- especially at the start of the game. Talking about the first impression is the lasting impression.. 2) After teleporting back to the ship, you can skip the "moving the box" puzzle#2 and go onto the next puzzle (the garden). Unfortunately, that will prevent you from finishing the game -- you will NOT be able to go back after your "drop" down to the Garden puzzle. 3) The Restore to Last Checkpoint does not resolve #2 issue.  4) There's no Save option.  The Save option would be a better option than the Restore to the Last Checkpoint and the multi-player options.  

Overall the game could have been much better if the designers/develops spent more time testing the game and resolve major issues ASAP.  This is 2019 and the bugs haven't been fixed since the get-go (2013).

55238703.review:
Very good puzzle game with excellent atmosphere. The primary game mechanic of cloning yourself and sending your consciousness to different clones sets up some pretty nifty and clever puzzles. The story gets revealed as you explore and is a bit thought-provoking leading to a rather interesting choice at the end. 

Though this won't be relevant for most users, I do appreciate that the game runs smoothly on my mid-2013 MacBook Pro 13", since my gaming is limited to whatever can play on that at the time of this review. So, it's a good game that can definitely run on weaker systems. 

The only weaknesses for me were:
1.) the game was rather short - I rather enjoyed exploring the environment and uncovering lore, and would gladly have spent a few more hours doing so.
2.) the hidden rooms mechanic was rather boring, rather reminding me of older games like Doom and Wolfenstein 3D in which you'd basically run around randomly checking every wall for hidden doors; I prefer following clues to find secrets rather than random trial and error until you find something
3.) It would have been interesting to have been able to see stats for the final choice to see how your choice compares to others who have played 

Anyway, overall it's a pretty good game, probably worth full price, definitely worth it on sale.

54412807.review:
Very cool game. 

The puzzles don't overstay their welcome as there's enough depth to the mechanics to last out the game.

It took me about seven hours to beat and unless you're a genius you'll probably get at least that much play time out of it.

The aesthetic, the art-style, the atmosphere and setting are fantastic and the basic premise of the story albeit a little cliche'd is worth putting up with for the backdrop.

One thing I didn't like too much was the writing. It had its fair share of the seemingly compulsory, nonsensical, indy-game, faux-philosophical, gibberish which is all too common in the medium (I'm beginning to think most indy-devs must be gibbering lunatics) but you can push past it without missing much...

...the story has a twist, which is appreciated and while it won't knock your socks off, pleasingly it neatly ties a bow on the whole thing.

Another complaint I have is that I found the written dialogue and voice acting a little obnoxious at times. One of the hallmarks of good writing is being able to enjoy the antagonist and/or villain, but here I did kind of just actually end up feeling viscerally hostile towards and  irritated by the acting and the script...it's not really a great sign when you feel like shouting "Oh shut up" or less polite words to the effect of "Go away" at the screen...

...for a prime example of what I'm talking about take a look at "The Old City: Leviathon" which, if not the quintessential indy-game for bloviated, nonsensical, wordsalad, philosophistry, is certainly a leading contender...

...a little like having some gibbering lunatic follow you around trying to impart his worldview to you...I know that you could argue that this was the point with TOC:Leviathon but you could also argue that this kind of thing  feels like it's becoming almost mandatory for the genre:  it's unfortunate but verbal diarrhoea seems to have, if not a permanent home in, then a long lease on, the indy-game medium. 

It might not be so bad if there were at least some internal logical consistency to any of the stuff, but for the most part it just sound like it's one bad re-write away from exquisite corpse.

The Swapper didn't have too much of this, but it certainly had it, and in a medium where this kind of  thing is all too common, a little bit wears out fast, and for a game with The Swappers' aesthetic it seems unnecessary and (apart from it being an indy-game) out of place.

This review might seem to be a little much for an indy-game with the scope, style and aesthetic of The Swapper but when you venture into such lofty territory as philosophies of mind, existentialism and the existence of the soul and with a treatment pretending to high-art (but with none of the subtlety) it does tend to invite criticism...

...it's a cool little game...that's all it needed to be.

54352474.review:
Note on a game breaking bug.  The game has problems with the cursor not working in it.  This means you can't even start the game.  The solution is to switch to the beta version called "compatibility" and the issue should be resolved.  Not sure why this hasn't  been pushed into the main game since it seems most people on windows 10 can't get the game to work in the normal version.

That out of the way let's get into the game.

The first thing I noticed was the striking visuals.  Some very interesting looking (organic looking for lack of a better word) texture work with good lighting give the space station a unique and very memorable atmosphere to the game.  I looked up the game and it turns out that the art in the game was not designed digitally.  Instead it was made from photographs of real life clay models that were made for the game.  This is what gives it that very distinctive organic look.  It's great.

The game itself is a puzzle game where you control a character with a gun that can make up to 4 copies of himself and transfer control to any one of the up to 5 copies in play.  These copies all move together as one.  The puzzles involve this mechanic as you try to collect orbs to progress.  There are various other mechanics that limit what can and can't be done in certain parts of a puzzle and even gravity changing parts.  It  plays well and the puzzles are just the right difficulty to keep things interesting.  Additionally, not every puzzle in an area is required to be completed to progress beyond to the next area.

On top of this is a fairly well done story about consciousness all set to a traditional disconcerting backdrop of a space station where once again humans have gotten carried away with doing experiments on things which they didn't understand resulting in a bad time for all.  Along the way you'll find concerning logs and messages of what has been transpiring.
