53804118.review:
[quote] This review is a part of the Completionist's Point of View curator (the link will be added once the curator is up) [/quote] 

The Swapper is a unique puzzle game with an imaginative sci-fi setting, good-looking claymation graphics (the majority of objects you see in the game have first been made from real clay, 3D-scanned and then put into the game) and thought-provoking story. When I first completed it, I kept thinking about the questions it asks for a few following days. I have a lot of sentiment for this game (mainly because when I finished it 4 years ago, it was my first 100%-ed Steam game), but even when I try to look at it more objectively, I still see a great experience I'd recommend to every sci-fi/puzzle game fan.

The titular "swapper" is a device with an appearance similar to Valve's portal gun that you find at the start your adventure and use through the entirety of it. The swapper has two functions: creating clones of its owner and [i]swapping[/i] their consciousness between the clones. This mechanic is a foundation both for the plot and for all of the game's puzzles.

The engrossing story is told mainly by text terminals and voiced radio transmissions as well as a few cutscenes.

The game is not a metroidvania, but its world is structured similarly to 2D Metroid games - you explore an abandoned space station divided into dozens of rooms connected by airlocks. Even though the space station is quite big, navigation is never a problem, since you always have a map of the explored area available upon pressing a button. All of the rooms containing puzzles are clearly marked and there is no item/ability requirement to solve them. All of the means and mechanics you need to know to solve every puzzle in the game are presented to you at the start of the game. The puzzles start out simple and have quite a linear difficulty curve throughout the entire game. The final ones are challenging but definitely doable if you spend some time on them. In my playthrough, I solved all but one of them on my own and only consulted a guide on the last one; but later I rather regretted doing it, since the solution was very logical and I could most likely have solved that puzzle on my own if I spent about 20 more minutes thinking about it.

[h1] Achievement review [/h1]
My time to 100%: 7h
Estimated time to 100%: 3-10h (depends on puzzle-solving skills, guide usage and reading through/skipping the text terminals)

[b]Warning:[/b] all 10 achievements are missable

The achievement design of this game is pretty much my only complaint. First of all, the game has a Point of No Return with no clear warning. If you progress past a certain point near the end of the game without getting all of the achievements first, you will need another playthrough to get the missing ones. Second of all, the achievements are rewarded for finding 10 secret terminals hidden behind fake walls (or ceilings) at various locations throughout the game. Even though I knew about it before I started playing, I only found 3 or 4 of the terminals on my own. Technically, it would be possible to find all of them without consulting a guide, but you'd need to be on a constant lookout for these fake walls, which is just not fun.

[h1] Suggested completion roadmap [/h1]
[olist]
[*] Play the game on your own until you reach the Point of No Return (PoNR). After acquiring all 124 of the collectible orbs, you'll get past the PoNR by pressing a special button you'll find on the space station near the end of the game. The button has a big label plate above it with an inscription suggesting that it's one of the final things you'll do on the station. You don't want to press this button before finding all of the secret terminals and getting all of the achievements. Here's an amazing, completely spoiler-free guide which will help with this task: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=196319766]From I to X / Achievement Guide & spoilerless hints[/url]. Depending on your playstyle, you can either search for the terminals on your own and only use a guide once you reach the PoNR or just use the guide from the start.
[*] After getting all of the achievements, just finish the game to see the conclusion of the story.
[/olist]
[quote] If you like what you've read and want to see more reviews like this one, please consider following my Steam curator :) [/quote]

I found my time playing this game to be very engaging.  The atmosphere in the game is great, conveying a great sense of mystery to the world that can feel menacing.  The game-play is very simple and intuitive, allowing you to create clones of yourself and swap your consciousness between those clones.  The puzzles in the game gradually become more complex as you progress through the game, requiring you to implement many of the lessons you learn about your abilities and effects of those abilities in some very creative ways that make you feel like a genius when you figure out the solutions.

This is an awesome game with a neat indie feel to the design and vibe. It's not so simple 'til you find it! Not as easy as some suggest although obviously that depends how fast the penny drops for you in each puzzle- I've got stuck so I like that it needs some thinking through, amusing seeing where you need to be/what you need to do then figuring out 'so how exactly....' Genre-wise a kind of 21st century Lemmings although it's a completely different game and puzzle mechanic, perhaps slightly more brain-frying too as you've only got four clones to work with not a whole horde of critters.

51276277.review:
[h1]The Swapper is an indie puzzle-platformer with great core gameplay, an interesting concept and decent execution.[/h1]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You play as an unnamed astronaut investigating a distress signal from a derelict space station. You discover a device that allows you to instantaneously clone yourself and swap your consciousness into these clones to complete puzzles, explore and unravel the mystery within. 

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b][u]Core Gameplay[/u][/b]: I really enjoyed “teleporting” around the space station, leaving my blank clones for dead. It appealed to my inner stockbroker. 

[*][b][u]Casual Horror[/u][/b]: There aren’t too many overt physical threats in the game. It was a nice change of pace to your average space adventure, like Doom 3, Dead Space, Alien Isolation, etc. The horror was in your mind.

[*][b][u]Real Puzzles[/u][/b]: The puzzles supporting the core mechanic were also a delight. 

[*][b][u]Level Design[/u][/b]: What I could see of the background, I really enjoyed. I liked the gravity shifting and weightless areas and each “area” of the ship had its own special theme. 

[*][b][u]Lofty Philosophical Concepts[/u][/b]: I really liked how they tied in the myriad of philosophy concepts like the self, consciousness, materialism, etc. It was informative without being someone’s doctoral thesis.
[/list]

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
[list]
[*][b][u]Lighting[/u][/b]: If I could make a single visual criticism about the game- it was WAY TOO dark. I hate when a game hides it’s beautiful artwork behind darkness because it’s atmospheric. YOU CAN HAVE ATMOSPHERE WITHOUT OVERLY USING DARKNESS!

[*][b][u]Pixel-b1tch1ng Puzzles[/u][/b]: There were about 3 puzzles towards the end of the game that were less about clever problem solving and more about clever cheating. Guess the puzzle bank ran dry towards the end.

[*][b][u]Meh Story[/u][/b]: The story is not that original or surprising, nor are the endings very satisfying since there was little in the way of character development.

[*][b][u]Brutal Hidden Achievements[/u][/b]: Without a guide, I doubt I would have been able to find even one. There were no visual or auditory cues, nor any instructions to indicate where or how to find them. They felt slapped on. Not cool. 

[*][b][u]Short Length[/u][/b]: Do we expect anything less from an indie title?
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Not bad for an indie game. If you can find it for less than $5.00 and you don’t mind alt-tabing to YouTube for the achievements, it’s worth a look.

50863865.review:
The Swapper is a difficult game to review, mostly because it is overall very mediocre. You are on a ship, overtaken by telephatic stones known as the "Watchers", and you seek a way out. You have a swapping device which you can use to create clones of yourself and swap between them.

That's the basic gameplay mechanic that never really changes, and I really wish they would've done more with it. The difficulty of the puzzles mainly comes from restricting colored beams. Red lets you create clones, but not swap to them. Blue lets you swap with clones, but not create them. Purple prevents you from doing either. So you try to juggle around with these beams in probably around 30 or so puzzles (it might have been less), getting progressively more difficult.

Now, something the game does well, is atmosphere. The graphic style is interesting and very well done, and you really feel like you're on an abandoned, creepy space station. You want to press forward and explore the mystery fully - however, this is also where the game's biggest problems lie:

[b]Creativity:[/b] As stated, the game mainly revolves around the basic mechanic of creating clones and swapping between them. Then there's the colored beams - and that's it. While the puzzles get progressively more difficult and they are never unsolveable, they are also not very creative by any stretch of the imagination, mostly because the basic gameplay loop is always the same and never expands like in other puzzle games (with new traps, mechanics etc.) The last few puzzles use a gravity switch, but other than that, nothing. The other problem is also that the game is very formulaic: To advance, you need a specific number of orbs to activate consoles that clear the way; so you go to a puzzle hub area, clear the 3 or 4 puzzles that are all in their own room, and then leave. There are pretty much never puzzles that you need to actually solve to clear the way in the first place, or to navigate the space station, or anything. You just solve the puzzles in their own rooms until you have enough orbs to get to the next rooms. Boring.

[b]Story:[/b] While this could definitely be a "me"-problem, the story just didn't make sense to me. The more the game went on, the more it devolved into a story that tried to be way too deep for it's own good. They even had a good basic story there - like, what happens when you just endlessly create and kill clones of yourself just to advance? But that's sadly not where the story went, and in the end I was left a little confused. It seemed like a jumbled mess to me, and in an atmospheric puzzler, I would've liked to see it explained a bit better.

Overall though, it's not a terrible game. If you have a few hours to kill, it provides some good brain training and the atmosphere is great. Sadly, I think there was much more that could've been done with the gameplay, though, and the story should've been a lot more clear.

Personal Rating: 6/10.

49925028.review:
[h1]The Swapper Is a Gem[/h1]

[b]Intro[/b]
I don't even remember how I got this game; it must have been part of some bundle I used to flesh out my steam library years ago. Boy, am I glad I decided to give it a try! I enjoyed every aspect of this brilliant little game.

[b]What is it?[/b]
The Swapper is a 2D puzzle-based platformer (with a much heavier accent on puzzle solving than actual platforming). It's a "platformer" in the same way Portal is a "first-person action game." Unlike Portal, The Swapper's puzzles involve creating clones of yourself and strategically placing them around a room in order to reach a certain object.
The swapper device lets you switch between the clones that are in your line of vision, but the trick is that all the clones move synchronously. To make it more interesting, there are certain kinds of light that either block the swapping or do not let you create clones in their radius. Finally, there is a mechanic of changing the gravitational pull of your clones (kind of like in VVVVVV).
All in all, the difficulty of the puzzles is similar to Portal - some of them you pretty much solve as you go, while others might give you pause and make you go "huh!" until you figure them out. Pretty light and casual, but still very satisfying.

[b]What's so cool about it?[/b]
Now, clever puzzles is not what made this game stand out for me. It's The Swapper's amazing aesthetic, atmosphere, and story. In terms of visuals and audio The Swapper is very in tune with LIMBO. These two games share the same sort of muted beauty that perfectly fits their melancholic tone. Coincidentally, the physics of character's movement are also very similar. As you explore the station solving puzzles and opening up new areas (almost in a metroidvania fashion), a very cool sci-fi story with a philosophical undertone unfolds around you, culminating with a tough decision you have to make in the very end. I love how the whole cloning mechanic feeds into the story.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
The Swapper combines brilliant 2D puzzles with a beautiful ambient environment and a neat story, and does not overstay its welcome.

48386034.review:
Great game! Wholeheartedly recommended!
The discussion between (David) Chalmers and (Daniel) Dennett is so funny, especially because in real life these two have probably also never agreed on anything related to the "hard problem" of consciousness. The storyline of this game goes far beyond any game I have ever played before. I actually wonder what the background of the developers is... The plot is partly bonkers sci-fy, partly serious philisophy. However, the sci-fy part of the game is quite a fitting illustration of the mind-body/brain duality that is the focus of the discussion between Chalmers and Dennett.
The puzzles are fun to solve, and some of them took me quite long to figure out. The strategy that worked best for me, was to (mentally) start at the goal and work backwards to the starting point. Another tip is that the straight path will always turn out to be a dead end.
The game is rather short (for its 14 euro pricetag) but easily makes up with quality for the lack of quantity.

Ok puzzle game. You create copies of yourself who move exactly as you. You can exchange yourself with the copies in order to collect an orb at each puzzle.

There's some story to it, related to an alien life form. It's not wonderful or very clear, but it tries to explain at its best why you can do the copy thing.

Puzzles are ok, but not outstanding. Later on, the game introduces a new mechanic: a gravity switch, which I really hated. There was little left of the game so as to introduce this. Also, last puzzles were pretty difficult.

Music is almost nonexistent. Sounds are ok. The astronaut walks funnily. Graphics are kind of good, but a bit repetitive.

All achievements are about hidden consoles or so, and therefore I didn't got even one. Would have been better to tie this to your game progress.

Also, the game has two endings, but doesn't keep your last savegame. You end the game, click continue, and here you have the credits. I had to watch the second ending on youtube. Bad move.

It's mostly ok.

47933112.review:
The Swapper is a puzzle game in which you use a device to create clones and swap your "soul" between the clones to solve puzzles. You are on a derelict space station, and as you progress through the story, you unravel the mystery of what happened there, and work towards your escape.

The puzzles are quite good, though not the best in genre. Most are satisfyingly challenging, but I did not experience any "epiphany" moments that other games are capable of inducing. One or two at the very end are more annoying than puzzling, requiring some precise platforming ability uncharacteristic of most of the puzzles. 

The game manages to use its clever mechanic to construct a story and theme dealing with the existential and psychoanalytical nature of consciousness, which you're especially likely to enjoy if you're already interested in that topic. Regardless, it's an interesting theme which isn't often explored in video games.

Ultimately, this is a good, if not great, puzzle game. It's thought-provoking nature pushes it over the bar. Well worth the time and money spent to play it.

47328745.review:
Every now and then a game comes along that makes me wonder how a premise so simple and brilliant hadn’t yet been created. The gameplay of The Swapper is easy to grasp, but it is  cleverly pushed to the point of creating challenging, yet deeply satisfying physics based puzzles. The Swapper combines its ingenious puzzle mechanics with a dark sci fi story, a gorgeous, creepy atmosphere, and plenty of mysteries that slowly unravel over the course of its all too brief six hour campaign.

In The Swapper you are tasked with exploring an abandoned space station and find out what happened to its crew while trying to escape yourself. The game is mostly a puzzler, with Metroidvania elements thrown in. The main gimmick revolves around the use of the “swapper” device, which gives you the ability to create up to four clones and then transfer your consciousness between them. However, each clone follows the same movement as the one you are currently inhabiting. If you move right, all your clones move right, if you jump, all your clones jump, etc. In this way it almost feels like you are remotely controlling your clones, which can feel clumsy at first, but soon you learn to master the system and manipulate it to accomplish your goals.

Like other art house platformers and sci fi before it, The Swapper asks some deep, philosophical questions about the nature of consciousness, the soul, what it means to be alive, and what it means to kill. Like its ancestors Metroid and System Shock before it, you’ll read logs detailing the events that led up the space station’s demise, slowly unveiling a horrifying fate. While the setting is classic science fiction, the themes are very human - greed, quest for knowledge, and the dangers of exploration and conquest form a cautionary tale. While the game certainly has some  cliches, its primary threat certainly subverts the genre and its final reveal is both shocking and believable, building from the mechanics of the game itself and the questions asked along the way.

While The Swapper may look like a classic metroidvania on the surface, it lacks a few staples of the genre. There are no enemies to fight, (mostly no) upgrades to acquire, and not much backtracking to be done. While you do explore and slowly uncover a large map, the gameplay almost exclusively revolves around its ingenious puzzles. The goal of each puzzle is simple - touch an orb with the clone you are currently inhabiting. Collect enough orbs and you are able to progress deeper into the space station. New puzzle elements are introduced over the adventure which increase their complexity and difficulty while keeping the player interested. This includes classic devices such as switches and blocks as well as more unique elements like areas that block your swapper and areas that switch the pull of gravity. And if you happen to be stuck on one particular puzzle, you usually have the ability to move on to other ones and come back later.

The puzzles themselves are some of the best in the platformer genre, often testing your spacial awareness, planning, and problem solving. Balancing the actions of four clones can be quite a bit to process, as getting one clone to do what you want often results in another clone falling to his death. However, the difficulty curve is nearly perfect, as the first couple of puzzles are nice and easy and slowly introduce you to the game’s mechanics. By the end of the game, the puzzles will require your logic and deduction skills to be on full throttle.

My only issue with some puzzles was that a few seemed to rely on very precise maneuvering, almost down to the pixel. In a few instances I thought a solution didn’t work, but it turned out I just needed to stand in exactly the right location, aim my swapper in this other precise spot, etc. In a game like this, I’d rather spend more of my time figuring out the big picture solutions rather than fine tweaking my reticle. Fortunately, this didn’t happen often and didn’t hamper my overall enjoyment of the game.

None of the puzzles, even the ones at the very end, felt unfair. I never found myself needing to lookup solutions and I found my progress to be slow and steady until I knew exactly how, when, and where to setup all my clones. And when you finally do solve a tough puzzle, it really feels like each clone is part of a larger machine, doing its part in harmony with the other clones to reveal the solution.

The art style and sound design in The Swapper is superb. The visuals definitely took inspiration from other deep space horror franchises like Alien, with dark corridors connecting abandoned labs now overgrown from their neglect. Dim, flickering lighting amplifies the mystery and dread of the station as you feel a constant sense of isolation. The characters and models have a distinctly clay feel, and while claymation is often associated with old christmas specials, it doesn’t detract from the game’s creepy atmosphere. You truly feel like you are far from home, and while there are no obvious and immediate threats, you don’t feel safe. There is the ever lingering feeling that whatever killed the people aboard the station is still out there, watching and waiting. The music is mostly Brian Eno style ambient, with gentle effects used for things like orb collection or swapper use. While it definitely captures the loneliness and permanence of space, the music certainly could have gone in a more horror centric direction. I assume the designers chose not to pursue this avenue because they didn’t want the player to be too stressed. Perhaps the best moment of sound design is the choice to use none at all - whenever you leave the station and are floating through space, the music stops all together, perfectly encapsulating the infinite void that is space. But lack of scary music aside, it is a beautiful soundtrack you could get lost in while wrapping your mind around the game’s intricate puzzles.

The Swapper is the perfect marriage of atmosphere, plot, and mind bending puzzles. While the setup is familiar, the payoff is far from it. This is a game that makes you think - not just about the challenging puzzles, but about some of life’s biggest questions: what is the soul, what is life, what is consciousness. You won’t kill a single enemy or do much of any platforming, but if you love physics puzzlers and great science fiction, you’ll love The Swapper.

9.1/10

45742436.review:
[h1]The Swapper[/h1]
I Saw this game on a sale in the Steam Store and got interested when I watched video and pictures. The ratings were in the end the deciding factor, so let me return the favor.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]The Swapper[/b] is at its core a puzzle game which has a "metroidvania" exploration vibe to it. By solving different puzzles you will progress further and use portals to navigate through the map. The core mechanics of the gameplay is creating clones which you can switch between "Swap" and even slow down time to make precision swapping possible. Each clone is expendabel and you really never have a true dedicated body. That is of course only half true as when you occupy a body, can die from fall damage etc. You could by this logic try to explain it all by saying that swapping means transferring your concious, allthough that is not the "real" truth.

There is a set amount of clones that can be there at the same time. They disappear if they die by fall damage or mechanics etc. another way is simply going through the clones with the clone you currently occupy which makes every clone it touches disappear. The tricky part is that while you only "truly" ocupy one you still jump or move all the clones at the same time. This together with the different mechanics is what makes the puzzles interesting.

I do not think that any of the puzzles were "too difficult". The hard part about the game is exploration. I had a hard time making myself play this game, so I used a guide. The puzzles I did on my own beacuse that was what was the fun part for me, but the 10 achievements... I would probably have found [u]one[/u] at best. Given that, I would say that there is fun for both those who like exploration aswell as the "brain-teasing" puzzles with minor platforming, who do not want to bother with the exploration part. Depending on who you are, decide if a guide is for you or not. 

[h1]Other parts[/h1]
The setting of the game is facinating! The graphic is clear and nice to look at while the atmosphere of space and the station? is mysterious. The atmosphere together with the graphics, the mechanics, the story and controls all make "The Swapper" into a unique game through the quality of all parts. The most memorable part would be the story, atmosphere and the [b]Swapping[/b] of course. I must admit that I need to replay and better study the story as I was tired when I rushed through the game. Especially since the ending peaked my interest a bit.

[h1]To Conclude[/h1]
[list]
[*] Puzzlegame
[*] Exploration
[*] Mysterious
[*] Nice gameplay with satisfying mechanics
[*] 10 achievments (hard to find)
[*] Can be finished around 5 hours with guide and solving puzzles without help
[*] Great immersive environment
[*] Fantastic atmosphere with stunning graphics
[*] High quality in all aspects
[*] Great story
[*] -Might be unappealing to those who like a more direct approach without to much exploring or navigating where you are.
[/list]

[b]The Swapper[/b] is a very well made game which shines with its unique vibe of high quality and ingenuity. For me the exploration was a bit of a hinder but could still be a very enjoyable experience by having a guide "holding my hand" throughout the game. As said before the achievement (secrets) are very well hidden and none of the puzzles felt too hard. You might get stuck sometimes but in the end it is not that complicated and gives you a good "brain-tease".
I bought it at a sale for [u]2,65€[/u] which was well worth it. I have no idea how long this game will take to fully complete without a guide, so I will not say that it is a too short game.
I will say however that I can really [b]recommend it[/b] if you like me, like puzzles with some engaging gameplay. It might be well worth it at full price for those in it for the story and the exploration in my opinion.


[b]//ECE//[/b]

44421084.review:
The Swapper is a pretty smart and simple puzzle platformer revolving around the abilty to swap your concious with up to four clones of your self with a handheld Swapper Gun. Use the "gun" to place clones at a distance and "teleport" to their bodies, leaving the original body in its place that will move in perfect sync with you. Generally, the goal is finding orbs that will activate teleporters and other parts of the map to proceed further. Puzzles are designed in a way to make swapping difficult, such as lights that prevent swapping and lights that prevent clone creation. Generally, you need to find a way to activate weight switches to turn off certain lights or open sliding vertical doors.

The puzzles can get real hard and you may find yourself needing a guide to get to them. I was able to get a few on my own, and felt proud of myself, but the further I got, I really started scratching my head to how I'm supposed to get to certain places. I decided that if I needed to keep looking up a guide to complete the game, that I wouldn't enjoy the game on my own accord so I put it down. But don't let that stop you if are big into solving puzzles.

[h1]The Swapper is a worthy purchase if you're interested in puzzle solving and finding out the story of the sentient life apparently living in stones (or are stones?) and how they communicate and how The Swapper tool came about. It has great presentation that will hold up for years and even generations.[/h1]

44056252.review:
A fun, creepy, and quite difficult puzzle game all about consiousness and what being alive really means.

The puzzles are the best aspect. They start off very simple, but increase in difficulty perfectly, with the last few requiring a good night's rest to figure out. I have to say that for a few of them I felt like I may have solved it incorrectly, but I'm not sure.
The ramping is nice, out of the about 30 puzzles, every 10 or so adds a new twist so they never get boring.

The story, however good, pales in comparison to the other assets of The Swapper. I found it to be thought provoking, but bordering on pretentious at times. Also, many characters sound alike (this is done for a reason) so play with subtitles, or trhe story won't make much sense. One annoyance of mine is that there's multiple endings, but each one requires a full playthrough of the campaign. This doesn't really matter too much, though, because you can just look up the other endings if you don't want to replay the entire 4-5 hour game (although admittedly the second time should be much faster).

If you've played Little Big Planet, then The Swapper should look familiar. The same style of animation and environmental construction is used, but in different ways. This makes the graphics, in my opinion, one of the best I've seen in a 2D game.

The music is simple, but it gets the job done. Spooky? Long stretched out violin-ish sounds. Sad? Soft ambient piano. Each soundtrack adds so much to the immersion and ambience of the whole experience, and I would reccomend a good set of speakers to get the full low-end range.

So, is The Swapper the right game for you? If you enjoy challenging, 2D, story-driven puzzle games hat can be beaten in a few sittings, then I would say so.

44008455.review: Another 2-D puzzle platformer. There are so many of these now. No way you should pay over £10.00 for one. Get it on sale if you really like puzzle platformers, but I would recommend checking out the cheaper options out there, which seem just as good to me.

43952370.review: Good puzzle game that keeps you engaged.

43950817.review:
The swapper is a fresh take in the gaming industry and proves that great game ideas are not completely dead yet. Obviously as the title suggests, the game is all about swapping to get where you need to go. It's as simple as that. Since the game mechanics are pretty straight forward, I wont talk much about that here in this review. Youtube the game and you should rather quickly get a feel for the game.

As for if you like it or not, depends, this is a thinking wo/mans game. This game is bound to give you quite some headaches, but in a positive way, the way that puzzles usually do. And its quite exciting to solve these puzzles. 

But unlike many puzzlers, this is one of those that no more than maybe 2 or 3 of them really need youtubing to solve, or you do it like me, go nuts, go raging, screaming and yelling and spending more than 15 hours in the game to come up with a solution.

Some puzzles are easier and some are harder, the puzzles doesn't always get harder as you advance in the game, which is a nice thing, this keeps things flowing rather smoothly, and you can try different puzzles and get back to harder ones at a later time.

And let me tell you, even the hardest ones, are doable, I did them without Youtubing, and let me tell you, I ain't no genius, so, if I did it, so can you. However, I have tried to playthrough this game on 2-3 different occasions because of the rage when you plateau and can't really find the solution, but I didn't Youtube the solutions still, instead started from the beginning every time. It has been over 2 years that on and off (just for the I did tell you so)

Let me commend something about this fantastic game, the aesthetics of is out of this world. The music, the sound effects, the controls, the graphics, its all there and then some. The graphics are absolutely brilliant, seriously, they are nothing short of amazing, second to none, and so on. Just watch the trailer and tell me you are not amazed about what they have accomplished. And regarding the sound, it is spot on as well, blending in perfectly, and the narrative voice that gives you little pieces of the story, is absolutely perfect.

The game also lets you roam around freely and just discover things, however not like an open world RPG this is strictly mission driven. The game has smartly placed portals, so you don't have to do any unnecessary backtracking or going back and forth between puzzles if/when you like. That can be a real tedious task in a lot of game. If you want, you can "swap" or run to the other end of the level or just teleport nearby to the action. In that sense you are free by choice to get where you need to go as you please G-R-E-A-T!

I guess by now you know where I am going with this... You have to get yourself this game, it will be entertaining all the way through whilst you play, beside one or two of the complex puzzles. Are you one of these smart thinkers, then you can run it through in 2-5 hours, but that is money well worth spending. I would say around 10$-15$ is a great price for a great game, and if you can get it cheaper all the better. You won't be disappointed.

But just don't expect too much of the game either, what you see is what you basically get throughout the game. If you have doubts, my recommendation is play it rather than not.

Oh, and a final PS. There are only four clones of yourselves that you can make, which will be given to you immediately when you start the game, so you can't upgrade your skills or get anymore more clones, just in case if you ever have a doubt about during one of the puzzles when you are raging. :)

What is The Swapper ?

As any good indie title, Swapper gives a good impression for having a simple but very well done execution with rather unique ideas insert int its gameplay in this case the ability to clone and swamp between your clones, its a puzzle game with some platforming, the puzzles are well-designed and will test your abilities, as someone who loves puzzle games this one satisfied me a lot, it has a decent size for its type, took me around 4 and half hours to finish, theres a subtle story and lore building in the background as you play the game with a few pretentious moments initially but in the final act it really builds up, the game closes on a very memorable set piece, atmosphere and sound design are also another aspect that this game nails, I just had a lot of fun playing this game, solving the puzzles and cloning yourself was never been so fun, the only downside of the game is more of a subjective idea of mine, I personally found the graphics and overall artstyle kinda ugly, this game would truly benefit it was done on pixel art or something like that, the 3d models used here are ugly but this is just a part of the game that I wasnt a fan of, I think it would look better if it was a 2d game instead, its just an opinion, either way the game's visuals it didnt even bother me at all, I just didnt find it as good as the other aspects of the game

Swapper is GREAT game and the type of game I look for when I just want to have a chill fun time, Im currently TIRED of AAA games especially when it has become so hard to find a different type of gameplay that twists interesting ideas in unique ways to make a memorable and different gameplay which is exactly what Swapper is, the little 4 hours and half I spent on it were amazing and the indie scene continues to make me entertained with the crazy ideas they introduce, swapper gets a recommendation from me, for puzzle fans I would even say its a must-have game!

43414586.review:
Very interesting puzzle-platformer with simple yet thought-provoking puzzles and an incredibly creepy existential storyline. This is one of those games you need to play a second time just so you can say "Ohhhh, NOW I get it!" There are no real enemies throughout the game but the atmosphere is creepy enough that you don't really need them. The story is one of those that you'll be thinking about long after the game is finished. I've had to rewrite this review as I'm doing my second playthrough just to get my thoughts down accurately.

My only issue was that the puzzles were sometimes so frustrating that I just had to look up the solutions to get past them. I'm fine with difficult and thought-provoking puzzles but some of the puzzles had me scratching my head for no real good reason. Often the solution was the exact one I was trying except I had my angle slightly off. There was even one puzzle that required you to be so precise that I had to switch to mouse and keyboard just to solve that one.

4/5

Aside from my frustration the story was captivating and most of the puzzles didn't overstay their welcome. This is a game you really should have on your wishlist but I wouldn't suggest it at full price, wait for a sale. Everyone needs to play this game at some point but 6 hours of gameplay isn't worth a full $15 in my opinion.

EDIT: I realized the portion where I had to switch to mouse and keyboard was because the guide wasn't using the proper solutions. After using the proper solution the puzzles were much easier.

43248425.review:
Fantastic puzzle-platformer game with the wonderful mechanic of creating and swapping between copies of yourself that all move in unison. This mechanic is developed extremely well over the course of the game, with gradual addition of tricky obstacles, such as areas of colored light that restrict your ability to summon or swap to clones. What's great is that, 5 minutes into the game, you will have all the abilities you will use for the rest of the game firmly in your pocket. From then on, it's all about learning to use your powers and your knowledge of the game's mechanics. To me, that is a sign of a great, self-contained puzzle game.

The game also conceals a surprisingly eerie and philosophical story that I felt was executed VERY well (I recommend turning on subtitles - it will help you intuit more of the story from the game's dialogue.) The story is told through brief text logs and bits of dialogue, with a couple short cutscenes. I felt like it was paced well, and with a couple of excellent twists toward the end! 

The desire to reach the conclusion definitely gave me motivation to finish the last of the game's puzzles - some of which are downright devillish! I actually took a few breaks from the game to let my mind relax, and found that approaching tough puzzles with a fresh frame of mind really helped. Like any great puzzle game, the sense of satisfaction when you FINALLY pick apart a tricky challenge is IMMENSE. Overall, it is a pretty short game; it took me 6.5 hours to complete the game (including all puzzles), but it felt like more than that because of how much thought I put into that time!

The art style felt a little odd at first, but ended up suiting the game's presentation well in my opinion. The music is minimalist and ambient - not very memorable, but undeniably great for puzzle solving. I will say that the rest of the sound design felt crisp and excellent, though.

Overall, I highly recommend this, even as someone who doesn't often play puzzle games. The current summer sale price is a steal, but I think it would have been worth purchasing this at full price as well.

42956862.review:
[b]9/10 game, DO play[/b] if you like puzzles, platformers and horrific atmosphere. Easily 10-20 hours gameplay without walkthroughs.

[b]Gameplay: 10/10[/b]

The central conceit of the game, if you've seen the trailer, is the titular Swapper gun, which allows you to summon up to 4 clones of yourself, then swap between the clones to set a particular one as the "Primary". This is significant because only the Primary clone can collect the game's main objective: Orbs, the reward for completing each puzzle room.

At the start of the game, where a simple series of switches, walls and platforms are the only obstacles, this is relatively straightforward and a room might only take a minute or so. By the end, when swap-free and drop-free zones, gravity reversal zones, blocks and crusher traps come into play, you will probably be sleeping overnight on some of the solutions, after bashing into the problem again and again and again in the best puzzler tradition.

The controls are very tightly programmed (I played on pad), and there is a convenient slow-motion mode engaged whenever you position to drop a clone, so arcade-level reflexes are not required to enjoy the game.

[b]Graphics: 6/10[/b] The indie production values show here, but I do appreciate all of Facepunch's artistic choices vis-a-vis lighting and background design. It won't make your eyes bleed. Resolution switching works well (I played at 1920x1200).

[b]Sound: 9/10[/b] Excellent score, great use of ambient effects and some really good voice acting as well for the audio recordings you'll find scattered along the way. If you do have a decent speaker set, some of the low-frequency effects are a delightful bassplosion.

[b]Story: 8/10[/b] I won't spoil anything here, but if you enjoy movies like [i]Alien[/i], [i]Invasion of the Body Snatchers[/i] and [i]The Thing[/i], you'll appreciate the delightful horrific touches in the atmosphere the game provides. If you like fiction by the classic sci-fi authors like Aasimov, Pohl and Clarke, you'll likely appreciate the very nicely put-together story, told very sparingly via found audio, text fragments and the fleetingly occasional cut-scene.

[b]Overall: 9/10[/b] I actually bought this in a 2014 Steam sale, got stuck at a early-level room, then set it aside for a few years. Felt the puzzle urge come upon me and plowed through it over the last 3 days. REALLY enjoyed it, strong recommendation to any genre fans.

+Some tough puzzles (in a good way)

[b]Cons[/b]
+Achievements basically need a guide to complete

Quite a different type of puzzle game, at least from what I expected. Swapper has both puzzles and a story that will challenge your mind. 

While there are puzzles throughout the game, the story is the real drive here. It’s mysterious and while it does get explained a little, a lot is left to your own thoughts. 

Puzzle mechanics are neat. You can copy yourself up to 4 times. These copies will do the same motions you do. Walk left, your copies do too, etc. If the conditions are correct, you can also teleport to your copies. Also, you can “recover” a copy if you touch it. These are the basic mechanics to solve the puzzles and gather orbs which unlock parts of the map. The puzzles can get pretty difficult. I did have to look up a few solutions after I was stuck for a bit.

Graphics are great! Crisp visuals even at 1440p along with an environment well thought out to convey the loneliness of your situation. 


A really unique puzzle game which has cool mechanics and story that will have you asking questions about your own life. They nailed the atmosphere and graphic style which bumps up the score a bit.

[b]8/10[/b] Very good

42480574.review:
An interesting puzzle game that is let down by a bad difficulty curve, intentionally obtuse story and a dull, empty world.

The game starts in medias res on a derelict space ship with the core mechanic of swapping between creatable clones that mimic your every move. Beginning puzzles are good, the lonesome eerie atmosphere and sense of mystery carry the game well initially. Little snippets of dialog are delivered after every puzzle and sometimes when exploring but they never really relate to much and are more philosophy 101 waxing about the soul and what defines "you" etc. 

The problems arise when the game starts throwing hard puzzles at you, which don't have any hinting or foreshadowing at how to solve them, you just have to sort of try everything until it clicks, meanwhile the story doesn't really ramp at all, things are still hazy as ever and the once lonesome isolated atmosphere turns into a bunch of barren empty environments. When finishing a puzzle you get these orbs that unlock doors or interface with terminals, but it's never really anything of consequence, it's just a McGuffin that allows you to proceed, might as well have been stars from a Mario game, I don't see why individual scenarios involving power/oxygen/water/electricity couldn't have been involved to give the game some grounding, why on earth are there just random orbs everywhere?

There are also sections of the game where you have to leave the airlock, these sections have no gravity, and don't really serve a purpose. There are no objects in the way, the camera and your characters sense of inertia is disorienting (probably intentional) and your swapper is disabled. These honestly felt like they were there to break up the monotony of empty rooms but empty disorienting space isn't much of a step up. 

The dialog stays obtuse late into the game and playing starts to feel like work instead of being enjoyable as there is little to no sense of progress or really any reason to care besides the sense of mystery. I thought to myself "Do I really want to struggle through this puzzle to get a few lines of dialog?" That is when I decided I had enough.

Although the art style was great I feel they focused too little on the meat of the game, the scenarios, the level design and layout and the context to all the puzzles. Summed up I feel they didn't design a game around a hook, they let the hook become the entire game, everything else be damned and for the asking price, I don't think that's enough.

42478941.review: Nice game, good graphics and decent puzzles. But! Controls ruined it for me, completely. Not a fan of platformers...

42476733.review:
[h1]- - - [ Impressions ] - - -[/h1]

The Swapper is a series of spacial puzzles that revolves around a very novel clone-and-swap mechanic. The challenges vary significantly in difficult, even until the very end. Sometimes the puzzles require several precise combinations of clones, positions, and swaps, and sometimes it's plainly obvious from glance, requiring one one or two steps. As this is core gameplay, I would have liked to have seen longer, more tiered challenges, as opposed to a collection of small challenges.

Visually, the game has an almost "hand made" appearance. While this is creative and well executed, it left me wanting for more polish. The visual artists were able to craft something so interesting and, in many cases, stunning, yet the final steps of cleaning up animations (specifically movement transitions) were completely overlooked.

Finally, the story. I can't say I was impressed, but largely because I just didn't understand it. You get the sense of some sort of meaning or driving purpose, but the big picture is largely obscured by often difficult-to-hear voice acting and fragmented delivery. In fact, most of the challenges (collecting orbs, opening orb-locked gates) are never even addressed! Does this ship just leave orbs everywhere in case they need to operate? Why is it when you swap your clone lives and copies you, but when story characters swap the old body dies? It's all very convoluted to me, which is a shame, because from what I've read online is that it's a very interesting story.

All-in-all not a bad game, specifically if you like puzzle platformers. If you're looking for the story though, you may want to read up on it after. For me, personally, I am not a fan of puzzle platformers, and the lack of story or visual polish made it difficult to enjoy.

[b] PROS : [/b]
[list]
[*] Novel and creative game mechanic and visual appearance.
[*] Good range of puzzle difficulty.
[/list]

[b] CONS : [/b]
[list]
[*] The core purpose of the mechanical gameplay is completely unrelated to to plot.
[*] The plot of convoluted.
[*] Lacking visual polish, movement transitions.
[/list]

42371910.review:
I don't think I can write a review that does this game justice, but I'll try.

If you couldn't tell from the store page, the mechanics of the game are static; you can create up to 4 clones, and switch your main consciousness between these 5 instances of yourself, but they will all move in unison. Each puzzle's goal is to collect an Orb, and your obstacles are 3 colours of light - purple, red, and blue. (No point in explaining each function of these colours, much easier to play the game to understand.) The challenge each puzzle offers slowly increases as you progress further through the ship, so it never catches you by surprise. You don't need to collect every Orb before each milestone to progress, but you do need to collect all 124 Orbs (not individual Orbs - after a while they're collected in sets of 3, then sets of 9) to unlock the ending, so you may as do each puzzle while you're still close to them.

As for the story, you start off ejected from an unknown ship/station in an escape pod, implied to have happened against your will (from the way the character is flailing at the window), and you crash-land on a planet (Chori V) where you find a teleport to a space station, the Theseus. You make your way through the ship, at points coming close to somebody else who seems to be partly talking to you and partly to themself (I recommend turning on subtitles as it may help illuminate you more during these bits). As you travel, you piece together what happened before you arrived, from both sides of the story.

Now, I won't pretend to be a philosopher or intellectual and say this was 2deep4me (or u), but this game has definitely been more memorable to me than other puzzle games I've played, because transhumanism is one of my favourite aspects of science fiction, and both the mechanics and story revolve around it very heavily. As the player in any game, you're expected to take the game as it is, and not think about the bodies you leave behind, or strand in midair to fall to their deaths, or disintegrate to clean up any mess you'd leave behind. Instead, the story instead shows the perspective of the scientists behind the technology, who disagree over the ethics of using the Swapper but can agree they would do whatever it took to survive and retain their own identities. There are 2 crucial moments, one being 2/3 through the game, and is taken from you and is ultimately a decoy, and a second one at the end of the game where you make a decision, on your (personal) stance. Having only chosen one ending, I don't know what would've happened if I had chosen the other, but I found the final scene moving in the best way. The entire game was hauntingly amazing.

Bottom line, I would recommend this to anyone who likes good puzzle games with great story.

42088780.review:
I was incredibly surprised how immersive and interesting the Swapper was. I picked it up because I love puzzle games and the handmade art sounded really interesting to me- but got a lot more out of it.

1) The puzzles are great. You will have to rethink them a few times before you get them - some of the answers eluded me, and I had to look them up, to my eternal shame. The answers were obvious if I'd looked at it another way! 

2)The mechanics work well, movement feels good. I played with a gamepad, which I hated initially but loved when I got used to it. Very easy to control, swapping and cloning mechanics were superb.

3)Atmosphere! Holy shit! Traversing the space station is special - each atmosphere is different and has great music to set the stage. The free floating areas really hit me hard with letting you know how alone you are.

4) The story is interesting and builds slowly without being too cryptic and fake-deep, like many games I've been playing lately (Hollow Knight - I'm looking at you)

5) The art works extremely well even though it might be silly looking in full light, the models are kind of clunky but they contribute to the atmosphere perfectly and add a charm that a fully digital game wouldn't have. I was reminded of Reveal the Deep, which would have benefited from a handmade style.

I absolutely recommend going through the ship again after you've finished most of the main mission, and the setup allows you to see which puzzles you've missed to get to the ending which encourages this backtracking. Teleport points are far enough apart that you have to seek out locations and stones.

If you like puzzle games and are into atmosphere, get this!

41856823.review:
[i]The Swapper[/i] is a great puzzle platformer, that showcases just how important presentation is for videogames. 

The puzzles are incredible—at times they're incredibly tricky, but never overly convoluted (i.e. you rarely have to create long chain of events, but must rather play smart). The plot is an angsty sci-fi story akin to the movie Moon. Most importantly though, the game is thematically coherent, with gameplay and plot intertwined to create a haunting experience.

But the presentation is... eh. The murky visuals are uninteresting and clumsy, the music is just... there, and more often than not the lighing confuses the player instead of helping them scout locations.

Were its presentaion great, [i]The Swapper[/i] could easily be called a gem and become a cult classic. As it stands though, the game will undoubtedly be a delight for lovers of the genre, but is unlikely to win over unprepared hearts.

40732148.review:
A lot of puzzle games square away the puzzle challenge of their gameplay pretty well. They take a concept and run with it until exhaustion sets in (The Witness) or refine it so carefully that no matter how a gamer solves it, in a multitude of ways, the puzzle remains just as challenging for multiple solutions (Opus Magnum).

The Swapper takes gorgeous artwork and throws in a stunning story with piles of philosphical conjecture, and adds as much mystery and atmosphere to its gameplay as a sci fi blockbuster. The cloning and swapping concept makes for some extremely clever, challenging yet, ultimately, simple puzzles that will have you slapping your head and asking, "Why didn't I think of that before?" over and over. 

The Swapper is simply a brilliant game. Even people who hate puzzle games ought to play it.

Los puzzles no son especialmente complicados, pero sí creativos. Un par te van a dejar perplejos unos minutos antes que los resuelvas.

40584510.review:
[quote=][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/12146432-La-Cruceta-Inquieta/][b]La Cruceta Inquieta[/b][/url], mentor de Steam[/quote]

Parece mentira que, en un proyecto tan pequeño y sencillo, que no simple, quepan propuestas similares a las de juegos como Portal o incluso Dead Space; de hecho, y salvando todas las distancias, The Swapper parece una mezcla perfecta entre ambos, aportando además su propia personalidad.

En este caso se nos sitúa en una estación espacial abandonada tras un determinado incidente, a la cual llegaremos sin mayor explicación para pronto encontrar el "Swapper", un artefacto basado en tecnología alienígena que nos permitirá crear clones de nosotros mismos que realizarán exactamente los mismos movimientos que llevemos a cabo. No obstante, el hallazgo de este aparato no es sino la excusa jugable de una trama mucho más profunda y que sorprende aún más tratándose de un videojuego indie y de una no muy excesiva duración. Así, pronto daremos con la razón de ser de la estación espacial: un conjunto de rocas y monumentos extraterrestres aparentemente inertes pero que comparten una conciencia colectiva y son capaces de comunicar ideas. De hecho, su estudio supuso el germen que dio origen al "Swapper", comenzando con él una serie de acontecimientos que, sin desvelar más detalles de la trama, tratan temas trascendentales y existenciales como el alma, la muerte y el concepto mismo de la identidad personal como un acontecimiento que va más allá de lo corpóreo y que no necesariamente está ligada a un sujeto o, incluso, a un tiempo determinado. En este aspecto, The Swapper merece la pena, y mucho, ser probado.

Pero nada de esto se explicaría con la misma eficacia si no contara por detrás con un sólido apartado de diseño, del cual, The Swapper, va sobrado. Tanto es así que creo que es uno de los últimos títulos que he jugado que atmosféricamente hablando más me han impactado. Y es que nada más comenzar ya sorprende gráficamente con su construcción en base al modelado en plastilina, pero además lo refuerza con un fantástico uso de la luz y de los efectos atmosféricos, trasladándonos por completo a los confines del universo donde transcurre la trama y a expresar a la perfección la sensación de soledad e incluso de terror a la que llega sin ser un juego en absoluto de este género. 

De igual forma, el sonido juega también un papel esencial en la creación de la atmósfera de The Swapper, presentando un continuado uso de los efectos ambientales que enfatizarán esa ya mencionada sensación de soledad y que serían ya suficientes para acompañar la propuesta de este videojuego. Pero en ningún caso se puede obviar el fantástico uso de las melodías escogidas para momentos puntuales, puesto que su minimalismo, tranquilidad y belleza no supone impedimento alguno para enfatizar aún más el aislamiento y la tensión frente a lo desconocido.

Por último, la jugabilidad de The Swapper se basa en mecánicas de puzles, tendiendo que hacer uso del "Swapper" para utilizar nuestros clones a nuestro favor o intercambiarnos con ellos para activar interruptores o alcanzar zonas que nos permitan continuar avanzando por un mapa de estilo "metroidvania" pero que, una vez más, tampoco tiene nada que ver con este género. En este aspecto, y aunque en realidad propone algo diferente, me ha recordado mucho al estilo de la saga Portal, lo cual no es sino una fantástica noticia para los amantes de los juegos de rompecabezas; y recalco rompecabezas puesto que, sin llegar a ser desesperante (aunque en los últimos compases del juego esté al límite de ello), nos pondrá a prueba constantemente con escenarios cada vez más complejos y en los que tendremos que utilizar nuestros clones con inteligencia y habilidad, midiendo distancias y "timing" a partes iguales. Realmente al final se trata de un proceso de prueba y error, tras el cual daremos necesariamente con la solución, pero en el camino nos daremos cuenta de lo gratificante que en todo momento resulta su resolución. Lo cierto es que The Swapper es un juego agradable de jugar, que podremos llevar a nuestro ritmo y en el que, aun existiendo ciertos peligros, en ningún momento nos sentiremos acechados por enemigos que rompan la tranquilidad atmosférica lograda.

Resumiendo, pienso que, desde el punto de vista de la jugabilidad, The Swapper ya es una compra obligada para cualquier amante de los juegos de rompecabezas, pero si además a esto se le añade un diseño artístico y ambiental sublime y una sólida trama interplanetariamente existencialista, poco margen queda para que no se le pueda dar una oportunidad a esta pequeña joya en forma de videojuego.

40031159.review:
I've literally just completed this game for the second time. At time of writing, that's eleven hours. I don't have much to say beyond "[b]it's fun, the story's good, and it's worth the standard price[/b]", but to elaborate a little:

It took about seven hours to complete the first time through, and none of the puzzles are optional. They also don't need to be. For all save one (the same puzzle most players seem to struggle with), I found the solution without any outside help. For that one problem puzzle, I had to look up a step-by-step guide.

I'd say most puzzles are genuinely challenging, but not truly fiendish. Don't sit and stare at them, the best way to figure them out is to just keep failing. It's always possible to just reset if you need to. If you're [i]really[/i] stuck, just leave and come back later. The game's relatively free-roam and you usually can leave a given puzzle until later if you want to.

I'm not going to give away anything about the story, except that it was deeper than I expected. I encourage players to read every optional story element they come across, and to use the tools at their dispoal to the fullest extent.

I'm also going to strongly encourage a second playthrough. It doesn't take nearly as long once you know the paths and the puzzles, (I did mine the very day after finishing for the first time, and took the opportunity to grab collectibles) but it allows you to go through the story a second time, knowing how it ends. It also gives you a chance to try the game's other ending, if you want.

38841625.review:
Takes a fairly simple set of mechanics which allows you to spotaneously clone and swap to a new version of yourself, and uses it to create a whole slew of often very clever puzzles. (As well as a very rapid if somewhat disconcerting method of getting around.)

If that was all it was then this game would be good, but there is a lot more here, it looks fantastic, the sound is suitably ambient and responds well to the events of the game, and the universe its set in is surprisingly fleshed out considering you are stumbling thorugh a dead space ship with only a few terminals to inform you. It makes me curious about what else is going on in that world, on the other stations, on Earth etc.

On top of all that, the story delves in to open scientific questions and philosophy regarding the mind, aliens, mortality, etc. It reminds me a lot of the book Solaris by Stannislaw Lem, and has a bunch of the same themes.

It takes about 4 hours to get through, much longer if you want the extremely tricky achievements that flesh out more of the world, but Ive already played through once more and will probably do so more times when Ive forgotten enough of the solutions and situations it throws at you again. 

Its a fantastic game, atmospheric, compelling, even on its surface its a very satisfying puzzler, but if you want to look in to it more its about as deep as any game ever has been.

If you were given the power to instantly create a clone out of nowhere and be able swap bodies with it at will...
Don't you think it's wrong to just swap bodies without the clone's consent? But does it even HAVE the capacity to get offended? Does it even HAVE a "self" to begin with? Since it's technically just a copy of you in space? Does it even matter? [i]YADA YADA YADA[/i]

The game mechanics of The Swapper ties in well with it's style of narrative by showing the consequences of owning the power I mentioned. By tackling philosophical themes like "the self" and conciousness, The Swapper offers a sad yet innocent story that may or may not get you thinking about your actions. The visuals also add up to this theme with it's dark atmospheric motif with lots of eerily realistic textures decorating the environments... Beautifully put together and no heavy hardware required in order to run it smoothly.

The level designs are excellent~ 
The Swapper's spacial reasoning puzzles feel very similar to Portal, There are times when you think that the level just seems impossible to solve, but you know damn well in the back of your head that you just need to git gud. 

So in my opinion, if you love the Portal franchise, you'll love The Swapper~ 

Happy Swapping~

⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀[b]7/10 [/b]

[u][b] PROS: [/b][/u]
[list]
    [*]Tiene unas [b]mecánicas excelentes[/b] y muy bien pulidas. [b]Concepto sencillo, eficaz y muy bien llevado[/b].     [*]Utilizando el concepto anterior mencionado, hace que tenga unos [b]puzles muy divertidos a la vez que desafiantes[/b]. Como en cualquier juego de este tipo, los primeros puzles son sencillos para que el jugador se vaya adaptando a la mecánica principal, pero a medida que vamos a avanzando la cosa se va complicando y [b]no se vuelve repetitivo[/b] ya que se van agregando nuevos obstáculos (como luces que no permiten intercambiar o clonar en ciertas zonas).

[u] NOT RECOMMENDED [/u]. 
A lot of awkward/bad control schemes:
- [u] gamepad directional pad (+) does not work in option menu [/u]. Instead, only the R-stick and L-stick on gamepad are used to highlight the option selection. The PC mouse cursor is sticking to a point where no option can't be selected (see next point). 
However, all gamepad directional pad (+), R-stick, and L-stick can be used to select message logs. Inconsistency on the control scheme.
- [u] PC mouse cursor keeps resetting back to a certain point on the screen [/u] (like a magnet is attracting it back to that point). And, it is not fixed to a point, but it keeps changing places like it has a mind of its own.
- [u] PC keyboard WASD or arrow keys do not works in option menu [/u]. Awkward situation when my gamepad battery dies, and there is no way I can quit game, so I just ALT+F4 it.
- [u] awkward twin-stick control scheme [/u]. In twin-stick game, R-stick usually controls the direction of sight. In this game, it also controls the cursor position to place clone, and where the camera pans to. 
Most of the time, it causes the screen to pan to awkward position that obscures my view to place the clone. Though the game has a slow-mo mechanic, but to solve the puzzles requires precise and accurate positioning of the cursor. This control scheme breaks the game flow, and damage the enjoyment for me. I had to constantly fighting back to gain back game control.
This is the point where I want to try using PC mouse control for more accurate placement ...... oh, wait, never mind. Mouse is broken for this game.
- [u] PC mouse and keyboard are out the window for this [b] PC [/b] game. [/u] Feel like this game was originally designed for (and only for) console, where only gamepad is used. But somewhere down the line, they decided to port it to PC, with minimum tweak on keyboard and mouse controls. Causing this awkward control scheme.
[b][u]UPDATE[/u][/b]: use this [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1212814284]LINK[/url] to enable PC mouse and keyboard control. Shout out to gamer Stoked for this tip.
After all this time, the mouse and keyboard control is still not implemented by default.

37939557.review:
First off, wow.  I was very impressed with this game (and I am not that easily impressed when it comes to things other than coffee or pizza).  Puzzle-based games seem very very difficult to execute successfully, in my opinion--I've seen many a well-thought-out puzzle game start strong and then fall victim to redundancy rather quickly (Talos Principle, anyone?).  This game was just long enough to be satisfying but without dragging on to the point of becoming tiresome.  The story was understated but still fascinating.  This one is a headache, but in a very good way.

What I appreciated most about The Swapper was the way it didn't just hand me everything I needed to be successful.  When a new mechanic was introduced, the game didn't go all tutorial, it forced me to learn by doing, by experimenting with this new device I've just discovered, much like one would be forced to do in real life.  As such, the game was very immersive.  On the whole, the puzzles were challenging, occasionally frustrating, but far from impossible.  They took a little juggling, a little concentration, but I only felt hopelessly stuck a few times, and mostly this was due to overcomplicating matters.  On a few occasions I actually laughed at how simple the solution to a seemingly complicated situation really was.  Controls felt a bit clumsy at first but quickly became intuitive.  Graphics make for a bit of eye strain, but fit the atmosphere.  Music is haunting and absolutely spot-on.

I really did love the story; even if the gameplay lacked it would have made the game enjoyable regardless.  Pretty critical points are touched upon, in particular the true nature of identity, but it presents its philosophies subtly and without being preachy, which is always a nice touch.  If you let it sink in, this one will stick with you for a bit after you finish playing it, but you'll be happy to have it there.

The gameplay is quite unique, however, it shares some similarities with Limbo. There is no combat but the environment is usually enough of an obstacle and the puzzles are pleasantly challenging.  As for the setting, I feel like it was inspired by [i]Solaris[/i] (S. Lem) and the visuals have a Dead Space-esque feel. Combine it with an interesting plot build around the concepts of consciousness and you get a must-play for all puzzle/sci-fi game fans.

[i]The Swapper[/i] is quite short but you will get your money's worth, especially if you grab it on a sale. Also, if you enjoyed the setting, check out [i]Oasis (series)[/i] as the pilot episode promises a similar vibe.

The term "Lovecraftian" might be somewhat overused but The Swapper creates a brilliant "Lovecraft in Space" atmosphere. No jumpscares, just dread and this feeling of an overwhelming, otherworldly presence that you cannot fight or interact with. Best of all, the Lovecraftian element of the story takes a backseat to the main plot about cloning and identity. It's a looming background presence, aloof and indifferent.

You will spend most of your time collecting orbs with the help of your Swapper device. The puzzles are fun and engaging initially when they rely on understanding the mechanics and working around them. Some of the later ones rely too much on positioning and pinpoint accurate movement. It puts a small dent in an overall great game. I paid 3€ during the sale, almost criminal for what I got. Worth the full price.

36415945.review: If you like original puzzle games with an interesting story and good atmosphere, this one should be right up your alley.  I found it quite challenging at times (probably half my playtime was spent on just a few of the harder puzzles) and I probably took longer than the average person to complete it, but I think it was worth it.  I felt very satisfied that I was able to do it all without giving up and looking up some of the solutions.  Fans of Closure, Limbo and other indie puzzle games should check this out.  I recommend playing with mouse and keyboard rather than a gamepad.  There are a few puzzles that might be easier with a gamepad (it's difficult to hold the "interact" key in its default mapping while also using the directionals, but this doesn't come into play very often) but overall I found it much easier to precisely aim your swapper gun using the mouse.

[h1]Clever puzzles, but the story isn't as well explored as it should be[/h1]

An astronaut in a far away space station needs to find his way around using a device that clones him and swaps his mind to his clones. It had immense potential, but the great story and philosofical questions it asks weren't explored enough, giving priority to its puzzles - which only works until certain point.
It has a great mistery and ending, but after that, and beating the puzzles, all the magic is gone.
Buy it at a discount if you really likes puzzles and story - but mostly puzzles in this case.

[b]Prons[/b]
[list]
[*]Clever puzzles with simple solutions
[*]Intriguing story
[*]Great air of suspense
[*]Philosofic deviations of self
[*]Simple gameplay
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Only one save. If you beat the game, you're going to have to start over to get 100%
[*]Doesn't answer many questions it gives throughout the campaign
[*]Is more puzzle driven than story driven
[*]Replay value only exists if you want to make a speedrun or get 100%
[*]The whole "what is a soul?" philosofy of the story is not as explored as it could and should be
[/list]

36231455.review:
[h1]The Swapper...[/h1]

... came out in May 2013. I avoided it because I thought it's was one of those games that was popular because of it's aesthetic, looks and atmosphere rather than actually good quality puzzles and a challenging experience. I was so so wrong.

Everything they say is true. Read the other reviews, all the good stuff has been said. Read the critics reviews, they're spot on. And read the 'about' section in the middle of the store page.

[b]TL;DR -[/b]
[u]My rating:[/u] 5 glowing space orbs out of 5. (See below for explanation.)


[b][u]Review:[/u][/b]

The Swapper explores the iconic Theseus Paradox to it's fullest; how much can an object or, in this case, a person and their mind, change before they are no longer that same fundamental object or person.

What is identity and how do we defiine it, by the whole or by components, by the mind or by the body, by memory or by an active working consciousness, must we be animate or inanimate and who decides what exactly defines activity or passivity (maybe rocks are a higher, more intelligent being than humans but we lack the ability to communicate together). Is the core of a person contained in some ethereal soul or is it something more, perhaps it is something less.

Through the philosophical narrative within, The Swapper leads also to an existentialist exploration of the mind and body, yet I can't tell if the argument is pro 'existence precedes essence' or con 'essence precedes existence'. If we define ourselves by our ability to think and remember, a la Descartes, perhaps The Swapper is just a test to discover whether we are real. Whatever the answer, Sartre and indeed Aristotle would have enjoyed this.

The IGN review sums it up best for me:

[quote=IGN]The Swapper tempted me with ingenious puzzles, transported me to a fully realized science-fiction world, and made me ask questions about mortality and morality that few video games have ever dared to explore. 
Very few puzzle games have ever managed to marry impeccable challenges with a mature storytelling quite like this – there's no fluff or extraneous content here, only a prime example of how to create a tight, unforgettable gaming experience.”
9.3 – IGN	[/quote]

[b][u]Gameplay:[/u][/b]

[u]Difficulty[/u] ranges from easy to 'kinda hard'. This is a puzzle game, it needs a bit of logic and foresight to complete. If you can do the easy puzzles near the start you can do the rest - but it may require some patience. This took me 5 hours to complete. Some people say they finished in an hour or so, some people say longer. It just depends. I needed a walkthrough a couple of times but that didn't negatively impact the experience of the game. Nothing was ridiculously hard and there were none of those fake difficulty tricks so many devs like to throw in these days. You will [i]not[/i] get frustrated or shirty with The Swapper. The achievements are for hidden areas, but the hidden stuff are not crucial or even relevant to completion of the game, they do add reams to the story though.

[u]Movement[/u] is easy, never clunky, never laggy or glitchy. All areas are clearly defined and there are no places to clip through walls or get stuck or any of that nonsense. Also, there is an awesome in-game map which displays everything you need to collect or see. SImply go to an area and it will 'reveal'.

WSAD or ↑ ↓ → ← to move & LMB / RMB to swap and clone. Q for map. E to interact. F for 'log book'.

[u]Aesthetic[/u] of The Swapper is central to creating a fully immersive experience in the desolate Theseus space station. The ambient soundtrack is amazing, from the sound of the overhead lights flickering to the noise of air rushing through the empty station corridors. There are many ambient sounds and sound textures used in The Swapper, put on some headphones, close your eyes and you might as well be floating out in space, [u][url=http://youtu.be/at3RXrUwMGg]a trillion miles from anyone[/url][/u].
The artwork is amazing, this was made using clay models. What can I say, The Swapper is beautiful and nightmarish. Have a look through the store page pictures and video. I cannot fault it.

[u]Honestly[/u], I can't fault this game at [i]all[/i]. I had no issues, except my own lack of ability on three separate occasions when I was impatient and used a walkthrough. Thank you [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=149756530]noibn[/url] and [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=149937488]Black Vanilla Tea[/url] for your wonderful guides.

[b]My rating:[/b] 5 glowing space orbs out of 5.

A small little masterpiece. An absolute no-brainer for this amount of money.

Puzzles:
Every puzzle is written in a way that it doesn't require micro-managing your position, but you have to understand what steps you have to take to get to the goal. This game manages to use very little game mechanics to twist your mind in many ways. One may probably think 'what do I miss?', but you don't. You just need to think in a different way. 

Controls: 
I find this game much more playable with mouse and keyboard, but that may be a personal preference. A certain amount of speed and accuracy is required while aiming your clones, but the gamepad worked just fine (I'm just not used to it as much).

Story: 
This is where the game really kicks in, in my opinion. The atmosphere is very unique, it feels like watching a movie while puzzling. The subject of existentiality may be a little much at some points, but I found it very well-told. The finale really gave me goosebumps.

Juego de rompecabezas de atmósfera espacial y ciencia ficción, con un diseño de niveles muy interesante y con una curva de dificultad bastante equilibrada. La estructura de niveles se conecta a partir de un mapa de diseño "metroidvania" en el que hay espacio para una suerte de historia con un trasfondo de corte filosófico y donde se tratan temas como el alma, la existencia, la muerte e incluso Dios.

La gracia de los rompecabezas recae en el denominado "swapper", un artilugio que nos permite crear clones de nosotros mismo y poseerlos a voluntad, dando pie a todo un conjunto de esquemas jugables muy adictivos y, según el transcurso del juego, sesudos en los niveles más complejos. No llegarás a quedarte bloqueado como tal en todo el juego, pero sí que tendrás situaciones en las que pasarás tiempo dándole vueltas a un mismo nivel hasta dar con su solución.

Los únicos puntos que destacaría a menos son que la duración es bastante contenida, entre 5-6 horas, y que no esta doblado al castellano, aunque podréis encontrar en la red un parche no oficial para subsanar esta cuestión. Por todo lo demás es un videojuego muy recomendable si se busca un entretenimiento directo y que te plantee un reto intelectual.

34947315.review:
8/10

A really good, atmospheric brain teaser that was just the right amount of tricky for me. I bought it not really knowing it was a puzzle game (not my favourite genre) but I was hooked from the moment I launched it.

Things I Liked

- The puzzles. Obviously this is the bulk of the entire game. Never too hard, never too easy. Although saying that, there was ONE puzzle I had to look up. :-) But thankfully a lot of other people struggled with this one too so I didn't beat myself up too much!

- The atmosphere. Eerie, cold, dark and reminiscent of dead space without the jump scares/horror.

- The lack of back tracking and very linear progress. When I first realised that the game would be made up of one giant area to explore I worried that there would be much confusing backtracking. But no, although there is a little backtracking, it's very easy to navigate from one area to the next.

Thing I Didn't Like

- The graphics were a little bit blurry. Not a massive deal but noticable.

- The voice actors sounded identical. Especially the women. This made it hard to follow the plot.

- The story itself was not anything special. I was definitely playing for the puzzles alone.

- Not much replayability factor.

- The music was ok, but there was nowhere near enough of it. I much preferred the soft tinkling piano tracks I got in a few of the puzzle rooms to the ambient humming of most of the others.
